author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1710075434}
review:
Belladonna is a Monkey Island/Day Of The Tentacle style point and click 2D adventure game.  This one has a Mary Shelley's Frankenstein theme as you take on the role of a re-animated woman with amnesia who must piece together what happened to her by picking up oddly strewn journal pages from various characters associated with this incredibly short murder mystery.

I guess one of the key rules of Steam that a lot of developers really don't consider is that your game really has to have more content than 2 hours worth, so gamers can't just buy your game, finish it and then refund it.  I'm not at all advocating anyone does this, but developers really need to provide more value to gamers to prevent such thoughts from even crossing gamers minds.  Especially considering the price of this game, because you can knock this out in about half an hour... and the content you could get 100% from by just watching a YouTube playthrough.  So why bother paying for this?  It's just a terrible business model. 

I won't spoil the plot, it's nothing remarkable.  The artwork is okay but mostly static stuff with some very rigid, clunky animation.  The voice acting is really mediocre.  The puzzles and gameplay are very simple, shallow and uninteresting. This is no Monkey Island. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The game features mostly static, barely animated 2D images, the kind of thing you expect to see in browser/flash games.  While the artwork itself, while mediocre, might be considered passable, the visual presentation here is negligible, it might as well be a slideshow or a Youtube video.  Pac-Man, Space Invaders and Asteroids had more advanced animation and visuals going on than this game does.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this only happened once, around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Belladonna has the farcical price of around $7 USD, it's not worth it given the defects and shortcomings with the product, especially considering the sheer number of completely free, much higher quality games on Steam.  For comparison, the $7 asking price for this game could get you games like "Ark: Survival Evolved", "DOOM" or "Mass Effect 2".  Quality, professionally made games like those are frequently on sale cheaper than this.  There's also thousands of free, superior quality games on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1655034977}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happineass of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054279933', 'num_games_owned': 1480, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1702662258}
review:
Why was this game even created? The puzzles might suit a kid starting their first point-and-click game, but the story not. Let me clarify, it's not frightening, just incredibly nonsensical, presented through endless walls of small text. The voice acting isn't terrible, but it certainly could be much better. The main character comes off as what some would call a "pizza cutter" ‚Äî all edge and no point. However, that edge is quite dull; it's reminiscent of a 15-year-old attempting to be edgy. Also, in this day and age, relying solely on a "forbidden love" storyline isn't sufficient for an entire plot.

A helpful suggestion for the creator: Implementing a double-click feature for doors would significantly enhance gameplay, allowing instant passage instead of repeatedly traversing the halls slowly.

Moreover, the game falls short in length; obtaining all the trading cards necessitates leaving it running while engaging in more enjoyable activities. It only took me 65 minutes to complete, and I'm certain someone more adept at these games could finish it much faster.

review:
Gothic horror Pn'C, very simple, very short, completed in 1 hour, including the pixel hunting (no hot spot key) and the backtracking (no fast walk possible.)
It's so basic that it has no options menu whatsoever, and no save menu (you'll have to trust the thing if you need a break.)
The story doesn't make much sense, but it has its charm, it's fully voiced, and the art is nice.

Recommended simply because it does work fine, is pleasant, and costs next to nothing when discounted.

author: {'steamid': '76561199105197380', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 419, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1683543684}
review:
This game reminds me of the songs [b]Mechanical Angel[/b] by Sunday Driver and [b]Coin Operated Boy[/b] by The Dresden Dolls. I love those songs, but to me this game has an aura of naivety that I find annoying.
[hr][/hr][h3]What I disliked about the game[/h3][hr][/hr]
The stuff this undead woman says sounds like something a 15 year old girl says to sound cool, edgy and philosophical, while in reality it's just random nonsense. 

[b][i]"Imagine a library with a book for every possible arrangement of letters."[/i][/b]

Who walks into a library and thinks about that the instant they see a bookshelf. It's a library, get over it. I am very philosophical, and I like dark and obscure shit, but I do not walk up to some object and think. [i]"Damn, am I an object? No, I object to the mere thought!"[/i]

This game makes me picture some girl who likes playing with those zombie dolls and dresses up like a goth to stand out and be different while wondering why people call her a weirdo. Then her parents try to help her, so she stamps into her bedroom, puts on some Death metal and cries herself to sleep without taking her medication.

Also there's the cliche of cats loving milk. A kitten has to drink milk to survive. An adult cat is lactose intolerant and drinking too much milk would cause health issues. Sure, you end up killing the cat (I don't know why), but the game still promotes the problematic idea of giving cats milk. 
[hr][/hr]
[b]So that's what I didn't like out of the way[/b]

The game is easier than a lot of point and click games (which is a good thing, although this game still requires you to do some things that aren't obvious). The story is okay and the voice acting sounds alright, albeit it sounds a bit younger than the character they are voicing. I just don't like a few strange statements that are made by both undead women and it creates a vibe for me that I dislike. I think the game had some effort put into it and it's a short experience that Im sure a lot of people would enjoy. 
[hr][/hr]
Also, why the fuck is Belladonna thicc?

author: {'steamid': '76561199468404675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1675255007}
review:
Belladonna is a haunting and captivating adventure game that takes you on a journey through a twisted and dark world. You play as a corpse girl who has risen from the dead in an abandoned laboratory, and as you progress through the game, you unravel the mysteries surrounding your own death and reanimation.

The atmosphere and setting of the game are simply stunning, with a gothic and macabre beauty that draws you in and keeps you hooked. The point-and-click mechanics are well-executed and offer an immersive and engaging gameplay experience.

One of the standout features of the game is the longer texts that you're asked to read, which are inspired by Mary Shelley's Frankenstein. These texts add depth and complexity to the game, and help to immerse you even further into the eerie and otherworldly setting.

While the game is not scary in the traditional sense, it's certainly not for the faint of heart, as it delves into some dark and disturbing themes that are sure to leave an impression. Overall, if you're a fan of gothic horror and point-and-click adventure games, then Belladonna is definitely worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042620952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1382, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1675976087}
review:
[h1] Genre [/h1] Ein kurzes Point & Click Adventure mit Fokus auf Story

[h1] Story [/h1] Wir spielen eine gerade zum Leben erweckte Menschliche Puppe (so sieht sie jedenfalls aus) und sind in einem Labor ohne Erinnerungen. Wir wollen jetzt herausfinden wer wir sind und warum wir hier sind

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] Gleich vorweg, man hat das Spiel nach gut 1 Stunde durchgespielt aber um an die Sammelkarten zu kommen, muss man es 3-4 Stunden anlassen. Das Spiel hat mich sofort an Mary Shellys Frankenstein erinnert worauf das Spiel wohl auch leicht basiert. Es spielt sich wie ein klassisches Point & Click Adventure wie man es kennt. Wir klicken uns durch die Gegend und interagieren mit verschiedenen Gegenst√§nden in der Spielwelt um Kommentare bzw. Informationen von unserem Charakter zu bekommen. Wir sammeln auch einige Gegenst√§nde auf um diese dann, mit anderen Gegenst√§nden im Inventar zu kombinieren um sie dann wieder irgendwo in der Spielwelt verwenden zu k√∂nnen. Die R√§tsel sind allesamt sehr simpel gehalten. Die Story wird durch Handgeschriebene Zettel in der Spielwelt erz√§hlt. Story & Atmosph√§re sind gut und auch der Grafik Stil ist Fantastisch. Musik ist ebenfalls ganz ok

[h1] Pro/Contra [/h1]
+ Gute Story
+ Gute Atmosph√§re
+ Guter Grafik Stil
+ Musik OK
+ Kurz (f√ºr das was die Story bzw. das Spiel erz√§hlt ist es v√∂llig ausreichend)
+ Sammelkarten

- Leider keine Achievements

review:
Full review at: https://thegamehoard.com/2022/10/25/the-haunted-hoard-belladonna-pc/

Belladonna is a somewhat interesting short story with an endearing lead and enough little twists and touches to its narrative told mostly through notes. It handles its tiny plot well enough and progresses through it at a good pace so that you are able to mostly latch onto it as the reason to walk forward through a suitably eerie estate, but it does sting a little when the story wraps up suddenly and with an unusual image to go out on. The interactive elements are barely even barriers to progress unless you didn‚Äôt spot the right items to pick up and it feels a little generous to call the impediments you face puzzles, but for a brief tale on the nature of death and rebirth, it fills an hour well enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561199051451415', 'num_games_owned': 649, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1665294011}
review:
The artwork and music in this game were beautiful; the storyline and voice acting left a bit to be desired. I enjoyed the puzzles and thought they were sufficiently challenging and interesting, but just could not fully immerse myself into the game because of the disconnect with the main character. The main character's voice just did not match the vibe of the game at all and was somewhat distracting from me fully enjoying the dark and twisted theme that Belladonna was trying to portray.

While the story initially was intriguing, it slowly lost my interest the further I progressed in the game. By the end, it just bordered on the ridiculous and I was left disappointed with the conclusion. 

The game is definitely worth a playthrough just for the puzzles and artwork alone. I would not however, purchase the game at full price and wait for a good sale. 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198420034913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1658098737}
review:
An interesting game. I don't think it's worth the $6.99 other than to support the creator though. It's a classic point and click with a linear story. Sadly I got stuck a couple times because of my currently sleep deprived mind.

It's a sad tale with an ending that doesn't really feel like a good pay off (for me at least). The story, up to talking to someone (trying to avoid spoilers), had me curious and each note made me more so. I wish there were more puzzles, more complexity in the puzzles, and just more substance.

I love the overall story and think this game is worth it. The atmosphere, breathtaking. The music, enchanting. The voice acting for our protagonist, flawless. The animation, unique. I would love to see more animation of the like.

Overall I do recommend this game. Give our indie developer here some love!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004492389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 331, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1653467800}
review:
Not horror, merely a macabre point-and-click, and a short one at that. 0.7hours to beat. (the other hours were spent idling for cards). Not worth $7. Probably $2 or less.

The good: A fair point-and-click for a genre newbie, and won't tease you or pressure you into solving things within a limited amount of time or penalty of death. If you have this on your backlog, the short length means it'll be a cinch to beat in one sitting.

The bad: Both voice actresses sound like they're acting. Reading the journal notes left throughout the map is not required at all (really makes you think, why in the hell did someone lose all those pages in all those places of the mansion?).

Anyway, if you're stuck, googling a walkthrough tells you all you need to know since this game is pretty linear otherwise. All in all, a good concept with horrible execution, and practically no intent on deviating, trying things new or introducing a twist. Still recommend though, since it's not an awful game.

review:
Length <1hr

Belladonna is a 2D Point & Click game, about someone who has been brought back from the dead like the novel ‚ÄòFrankenstein‚Äô.

In the game items are simple to find, everything stands out and there are not many items that you can interact with that don‚Äôt have a purpose. Only thing I recommend is checking the entire rooms, some rooms can scroll for further area.

Belladonna is mainly narrative focus, though most of the story comes about through the notes laying around the manor, there is a lot of text that needs to be read to understand everything that is going on. The story itself is interesting though nothing amazing, and most players will be able to work out the story early on.
The game is short should you not take the time to read all of the notes, in my video the notes make up most of the recording time.

Overall the game has an interesting story, the puzzles were simple, you just find all of the items in the map.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013866056', 'num_games_owned': 2647, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1447803397}
review:
Gothic style point and click adventure, developed by one person, about a reanimated woman trying to remember her past, the relationship between Belladonna and her maid, and the waning sanity of her husband and his desire for her to be more like an obedient object instead of a person. Good visuals, and the way that reanimation of the dead is presented fits the game very well thematically.

Much time is spent reading, well written, if somewhat hard to read (visually), notes from characters that do a good job describing how characters are feeling and what they believe other characters are thinking. I'm not sure why you are able to find some of these notes scattered on the ground throughout the environment you explore, all characters mention keeping the notes hidden and secret.

The game has no real puzzles and it is a very short game that should take around an hour to complete. I feel like it would have made a better visual novel as the same visual style could have been given to the house and characters, the short cutscenes could still have been used, it would fit the style of not having puzzles better, and would have been an easy way to make the text that you spend most of your time reading easier to see for people that will have trouble reading it the way they are presented.

Some people will likely consider the ending to be a cliffhanger but I don't see how it matters or how it would be relevant to the themes explored by the game.

review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]Good things:[/h1] 

This game is a short and very dark point and click game. The more notes you find and the more you read the more evil this world looks. The good thing was how the zombies were created as that is a good idea for some other games. Graphic and voice acting was also one of the good things about this game.

[h1]Bad things:[/h1] 

I just think this game is short and feels more like an intro to a much larger story. Or like this game is just here to get us into this world and be an intro to some other more complex game in the presented world but sadly no more games were released in this world. The more clues and notes I found about what happened the more I despised everyone involved and in the end I even despised the heroine we play as.

Gameplay is super simple and you just click on all things you can as you will need 80% of these that you can click on and the rest are just flavor text. You can finish the game in one hour but you have to play for about 4.5 hours to get all cards so after you finish the game you are just forced to idle it just to clear it from your list of games finished.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1] 

All you need is one hour to learn the whole story and finish the game.

Overall score 4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197992677121', 'num_games_owned': 3279, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1631138652}
review:
Ah, Belladonna... Definitely not a bad game, but throughout the whole playtime felt like a demo of a larger, more complex game and story.

You basically pick up journal pages from various people and that's the only way for you to experience the story. If you are the skip-all-reading type of player, you will not understand a thing.

It is about an hour long (reading included) with very basic and typical point-and-click item interactions. It is decently enough fully voice acted, with great visuals and an awesome setting. The soundtrack is pretty mediocre, but no too bad.

Again, I want to stretch that it is not a bad game. But the story and especially the gameplay are too superficial and lacking. I would just love to play the full version of it.

It could easily be a 7/10, but now it's just an attempt of an indie developer that shows what they are capable of. As a game sold for a (rather small) price, this is a 4/10.

An this is why it's not recommended. If it was free, it would definitely be worthy a try, but still, you wouldn't miss anything skipping on it.

I hope we will someday see a full point-and-click adventure from Neckbolt!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005735219', 'num_games_owned': 3484, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1622102921}
review:
There's not a lot of requirements for a good point and click adventure game, but I'd say Belladonna breaks one key rule and that having the player sympathize with the character their playing as. At first I was into the mystery of who this Frankenstein girl was, slowly reading the story through the notes helped build that curiosity but as I went on my sympathy and interest slowly faded as I grew to not like anyone in dark story. Dreary as its meant to be I had little interest in finishing it but I played on and found I got to the ending even faster then I expected, only hindered by one or two objects just out of view.

If I had only played this recently I'd say it would be a bit boring. But having played two other Point and Click adventure games that were free and lasted me much longer and with a lot more to do and think interact with. I'd have say even though I got this game on a discount that its not worth your time. I'm sure with the amount of detail in the art and design someone put a good amount of effort into the game. But you can dress up a corpse as pretty as you want, but that doesn't mean it wont stink.

author: {'steamid': '76561198302208299', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1610415108}
review:
Belladonna is a a short Point & Click Adventure game though it's almost more like an interactive storybook.  The story is interesting but feels incomplete.  Overall, it was an okay game.  Not a bad way to spend 1-2 hours but also, nothing overly thrilling.

It's a Gothic horror style story based largely on Mary Shelly's 'Frankenstein'.  It does spend a good deal of it's time (keep in mind it's pretty short) on playing with the themes of loss, grief, death, life, having a soul, good and evil.  It also has murder, forms of slavery, jealousy, and a love triangle involving a lesbian romance.  It tried to tackle an awful lot in it's short run.  I think that in order to do so effectively it probably should have been a longer game more fully exploring those aspects in more depth or it maybe should have pared down some of the themes and concepts to give more time to the ones that they really wanted to focus on in this game.

The story is revealed relatively slowly so that you get bits and pieces of the story each time you progress to a new area.  The do this with the discovery of journal pages but it can involve a lot of reading.  While I generally prefer to receive game information in smaller chunks the format does sort of make sense in the way they are telling the story but it may have been nice if these discoveries could have instead triggered a flashback, been told through cut scenes, or even been discovered in other ways besides just journal entries.  The story is pretty predictable once you have a few pages, the biggest twist is probably that the lover is woman instead of a man and that's not particularly hard to guess either.

In some ways this story has elements that remind me of Anna's Quest or of Edna & Harvey in that the protagonist is sort of sweet and innocent but also seems ambivalent or oblivious to any bad things they do.  For example part of the game is killing a cat which the character actually seems to think back on in retrospect wondering if it's actually worrisome that she didn't seem to mind or care about killing it.  This is supposed to be a big part of presenting the good or evil nature of the reanimated and whether or not they have a soul and if it even matters.  I will say that while the overall story is withing the horror genre there's nothing that should really scare you too much.  There is a moment when walking to the other side of the room that you discover the cat and I wasn't expecting that so it did give me a little jump scare but nothing should truly shock or horrify you if you go into this expecting a Frankenstein style story.

The voice acting quality was decent and actually was fairly well recorded with the exception of some minor issues with volume.  However, the voices seemed out o place to me personally.  It just didn't feel like they went with the character.  Sometimes, they grow on you (like Michael in Dead Synchronicity, his voice seemed wrong for the character to me but eventually after playing a while sat fine) but these ones continued to feel somehow out of place.  Perhaps because it was almost trying to be a period Gothic piece in which case the voices sounded too out of time and place or they just didn't match the actual personalities I perceived from the characters.  It's a bit subjective of course but, to me they were just off not that the voice acting itself was bad.  The dialogue was a little awkward  a few times but, mostly well written.

The graphics are actually pretty nice and the sprites have a good design.  Walk paths are good, but there are some oddities such as when walking up the steps to the clock you aren't exactly on the ground it can actually appear as though your floating over it at the top of the steps.  The backgrounds have some nice Gothic elements but, sometimes feel a little uneven with some feeling much more ornate and detailed with others feeling a bit too sparse.

Game play mechanics are pretty straightforward.  There's a simple inventory where you can view what you've collected and you click on the item to select it then click on an active hot spot to use it.  There's no shortcut such as pushing the space bar to find all the hot spots on the screen but a title will pop up when you mouse over a hotspot.  So some amount of pixel hunting is required but, not much.  Pretty much all o the solutions to gather items and use them are fairly simple and logical to discover.  There is no quick walk or fast travel to jump to the next scene so you do have to wait for the sprite to walk the entire scene.  Not a huge deal as it doesn't take long but still would have preferred the option.  The menu interface is minimal.  Clicking on the book in the bottom left will open a menu that shows your found journal pages.  Pressing esc allows you to exit the game or continue.  The game saves your progress manually, so while you can load game, there isn't exactly a manual save.  There are no options for adjusting sounds or anything just 'Load Game', 'New Game', and 'Quit'.  

I did encounter an error when in the lab with Belladonna where she was blinking in and out of the scene and there was no audio.  When I went to pull the switch on the machine, it went black and then just seemed unresponsive.  I though maybe it was an abrupt ending but it didn't show an end scene or bring me back to a menu or anything.  I let it sit a for several minutes but that do anything either.  I forced the game closed and reopened it and it had me back to just before I pulled the switch and now Belladonna was not flashing and the audio was fine.  The ending was abrupt and did end there but there is a final end scene of Belladonna lording over her undead army.

This game unfortunately doesn't have any achievements  but it does have STEAM trading cards.  Interestingly enough it has a lot of them especially for a game of it's size.  There are 13 cards and 7 drops.  Unfortunately this means you will finish the game before the cards drop so you will either have to play multiple times or allow the game to side open and idle on your computer while waiting for the rest of the drops.  This game took me  a little over an hour to play I'll be generous and say 1.5 hours.  1.8 was my finally tally at the time of starting this review (don't forget it sat idle with it's glitch for a while, and I didn't time that)  During that time I had received 3 cards.  I had to let it sit open quite a while to get the others to finish dropping.  That's a bit poorly designed.  Partly on the developer for making so many cards to atach to their work knowing it was short and partly on steam because their card drop rates are standard but should perhaps be set to an algorithm that measures actual played time to completion to allow a better drop rate during actual game lay and avoid these types of situations.

This game's full price at around $7 is too high in my opinion for what you get. It comes out to about $3.50-$4.67/hr of gameplay.  While it may not be super expensive this game just didn't offer anything extra special that would make it seem worth it at that price.  I received this for free as a gift from a friend on steam and so I didn't actually pay anything for it but, I would have been disappointed had I paid full price.  However, this game does frequently go on sale for $1 or less so if you see it on sale I'd say it could be worth the price if your into Gothic Horror or Point & Click / Adventure games in general.  It's not likely to be on anyone's top 10 games lists but it's entertaining enough to enjoy playing for an hour or two.

review: For most of my playtime I was kind of lukewarm about this game; it relies far more heavily on reading LOTS of notes (spaced very close together) than it does on finding, using, or combining items, the story isn't exactly terrible but isn't exciting, and the art is nice but sparse to the point that the environments don't feel fleshed out in most areas. When I got to the point where the game requires you to kill a cat, though, that was game over. This is an absolute deal breaker for me, and the game isn't piquing enough interest to consider going against my instincts in order to proceed, so I won't be finishing. All in all I feel like there could've been a good game here, but it needed another round or two of editing on all fronts. This game feels premature, for lack of a better word. There are probably people out there who would enjoy it, but in the end I'm just simply not one of them.

review: Didn't really have a whole lot going on. Voice acting while good, didn't seem appropriate. author: {'steamid': '76561198239835206', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1609140385}
review:
I had high hopes for this game based on the art style. I was expecting a spooky, gothic steampunk sort of tale about a girl rediscovering herself after she died. I got none of that. 

The writing is completely in your face. There's no build up, no suspense, you're immediately thrown into paragraphs of text on journal pages that are strewn about the castle for no apparent reason. The main and only real plot twist becomes apparent about halfway through the game so it's no surprise whatsoever when the reveal finally happens. Everything else that is revealed was completely expected based on the crazily detailed journal entries. Several promising threads are explored, but nothing is ever fleshed out with them and the one time right at the end where I was actually intrigued to see what a character had to say, they change their mind and abandon the train of thought completely. 

There's nothing scary about this game other than the general concept of reanimated corpses and one glaringly loud horror movie sound effect that jumpscares you because it's so out of place with the rest of the audio. Nothing to peace together, nothing to solve. The gameplay is ridiculously self-explanatory. There's no challenge to be had, no puzzles to be solved. If there is something unclear, the main character will basically tell you exactly what you have to do when you use an item incorrectly. 
To top it all off, the voice acting is completely devoid of emotion (I have no clue why other reviews were praising it), and does not always match or sync up with the written words above your head. You can click all the way through to the end of the dialogue for that section and the game will still be playing the audio from the first line. 

In the game's defense, it's short, it's cheap, and it's not trying to pretend to be anything it isn't. There were promising ideas and concepts  toyed with, and I'd be interested to see if the developer has refined their skills in any future games. But as far as Belladonna, it's so unpolished that I can definitely not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097118288', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1606101100}
review:
As you can see I completed the full game in a little over an hour. I would have finished much sooner if I hadn't missed a key item at the very beginning of the game. The story it's self is mainly told through journal entries and honestly, this is the best part of the game, the beautifully gothic art style being a close second . I personally like reading lore in games so this wasn't an issue, though if it's not for you give this game a miss. I was however pleasantly surprised by the fact that this was a WLW spin on the classic tale of Frankenstein. 
The Puzzles are incredibly simple to complete, I honestly think my 10 year old nephew could play this full game without any help. If you're looking for a challenge this isn't it.

Pros:
Beautifully designed
Short and sweet if you want something quick to play
Pro WLW
I enjoyed reading the journals and learning the lore of the world

Cons: 
The puzzles are simple
They used the same voice actress for the only two speaking characters in the game, it's obvious and distracting.
You have to kill a cat at one point, I know it's just pixels but I felt bad
The game just abruptly ends. There's no real epilogue after getting emotionally invested in the story.

Overall: If you ever see this on sale, pick it up as it is worth a look, however if it's not on sale give it a skip. I enjoyed my time with it, but I'm probably not going to play this ever again.

review: I've just done my second playthrough of the game, after several years. No spoilers-- it's an interesting story. It's also refreshing to find WLW in something that ISN'T a visual novel. I find myself thinking more of its shortcomings, though. Typos, a badly animated protagonist, some elements shoehorned in for no clear reason while some seriously interesting (and some seriously fridge-horrific) elements remain unexplored, barely explored, or glossed over. I think some of this is intentional but too much of it is rushed. Would be nice if the developer were to revisit these themes in a longer, better game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160412661', 'num_games_owned': 2388, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1594340182}
review:
[i]Belladonna[/i]. Ich wusste vor dem Kauf nicht so richtig, was mich hier erwarten w√ºrde, aber es sah auf den ersten Blick interessant aus und kommt (gerade im Sale) zu einem schmalen Preis daher. Also warum nicht?
Bei [i]Belladonna[/i] handelt es sich um ein klassisches Point & Click-Adventure, in dem wir in der Rolle einer jungen Frau in einem eigenartigen Labor scheinbar gerade wieder zum Leben erweckt wurden und nun herausfinden m√ºssen, welche Machenschaften dahinter stecken. Und nur so viel sei verraten; die Geschichte wird bisweilen recht d√ºster und makaber, verzichtet aber auf allzu explizite Szenen. Neben der offensichtlichen Anlehnung an [b]Frankenstein[/b] erinnerte mich die Geschichte fl√ºchtig auch an [b]Re-Animator[/b], E.¬†T.¬†A.¬†Hoffmanns [b]Der Sandmann[/b] und (Spoiler!) [spoiler]das JRPG Mad Father[/spoiler]. Wem die genannten Titel zusagen, der d√ºrfte an der Story von [i]Belladonna[/i] also wahrscheinlich Gefallen finden. Erz√§hlt wird sie √ºberwiegend in Tagebucheintr√§gen, die im Anwesen, einem alten Schloss in Ingolstadt, verteilt sind, man darf sich dementsprechend auf einiges zu lesen einstellen, die Texte sind dabei, wie das gesamte Spiel, ausschlie√ülich auf Englisch, die Dialoge aber immerhin vollst√§ndig vertont. Die R√§tsel decken die g√§ngigen Mechaniken des Genres ab, sollten keine gro√üe Herausforderung darstellen und nach knapp einer Stunde endet das Spiel dann leider auch sehr pl√∂tzlich und an einer Stelle, die gerne noch weiter gesponnen h√§tte werden k√∂nnen. Sei's drum, Spa√ü hat es trotzdem gemacht und √ºber die mehr oder weniger subtile Frage, die das Spiel aufwirft, wo Menschlichkeit anf√§ngt und aufh√∂rt, kann man sicherlich einmal nachdenken. 
Unter dem Strich ist [i]Belladonna[/i] also sicherlich kein ewiger Klassiker, f√ºr Fans des Genres und/oder makaberer Geschichten aber eine kurzweilige Unterhaltung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073941274', 'num_games_owned': 3149, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1593889294}
review:
[h1][b]Frankenstein-Gothic-esque Point & Click[/b][/h1]

The story is intriguing with a good gothic style and a twist (interpretation) of Frankenstein.  I thought the story was well written with the notes and the dialogue.  The voice acting was lacking.  It was passable for such a small short story but much longer of a game and I would have muted it.

The ambient sounds and the sound effects were fine and proper for the setting.  The graphics were simple, not groundbreaking, but fit well with the gothic theme and were done well.  The controls are your usual point and click controls with an inventory system.

There are no achievements but there are trading cards.  You must let the game idle for an [u]extended[/u] period of time to get all the card drops.  You will most definitely be done with the game before all the drops have triggered.  I finished the game in about an hour.

There are complete walkthrough guides on Steam if you get stuck somehow.

[i][b]A short point and click game with a good story but nothing outstanding.  I would definitely get it while on a sale.[/b][/i]

review:
A fine short game.  
7/10, but a solid 7/10.  What I mean is, not much really drags it down too bad, but nothing really makes it exemplary.
If you can forgive the rough edges, you can enjoy this for it's playtime of about an hour.
The art is only so-so, but the main character's design is interesting.
For being so short, the story has a few twists and turns and ends before it becomes stale.
It really needs some volume controls.  The background music is a bit too loud and there's no options to balance it.
The voice-acting is passable, but with the occasional microphone pop or recording glitch.
At full price, it's a bit too much for what you get.  Wait for it to go on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106512564', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1584619318}
review:
BottomLine at the Top:  More of an "artistic adventure" than a real P&C game but still enjoyable.  For the P&C aficionado it's worth checking out but paying full price feels steep for what it is.


-------------------------------------
Pros
-------------------------------------
-I really like the overall feel of this title.  It‚Äôs a weird combination of gothic horror but with a sweet and innocent protagonist. It reminds me of a Tim Burton movie.
-Strange commentary and monologue from the main character.  I like weird s*** so I found it entertaining.
-I found it funny how opening a certain door uses the EXACT same sound effect as when a friend would come online in AOL/Instant Messenger lol.

-------------------------------------
Meh.
-------------------------------------
-No save slots.  It's a very short game so it‚Äôs not a huge issue.
-Minor pixel hunting.  Again, it‚Äôs a short/small game so it was not a huge issue eventually finding a few items.
-Game story background is told by journal pages which you "find".  I say find loosely here as it takes zero effort to actually find them they are prominently located in each new room you travel too.  I'm not usually big on reading a lot in games but on the plus side they did keep you interested in the story.  
-Gameplay is lacking.  Puzzles are very straight forward.  Combined with the overall art style and in some cases minimal animations it feels at times like I was playing a weird mashup of a hidden object/point and click game.  (For a game with a similar feel check out Hostil)


-------------------------------------
Cons
-------------------------------------
-Had to alter the config file to get it to play in the proper resolution in Fullscreen mode.
-Very short.  Ends just as the story was getting interesting.  I'm not sure how much of this was an artistic choice versus running out of time/funding to complete the game.  
-No double click fast travel.
-Skipping dialog by clicking ends up advancing the text but the sound file for the dialogue continues to play.  This ends up just getting the two out of sync and I felt was kind of sloppy.


Final Thoughts:  As another reviewer stated this game took on many themes at once of same sex relationships, domestic abuse, and dealing with loss as well as the gothic themes of life and death and what it means to have a soul.  How well it accomplished this depends on how you look at the game as a whole.  If it was meant to be more of an art project, then I think it kind of works.  If it was meant to be a standalone adventure, I think it really would have needed to be a longer game.  You get a glimpse of what this game could have incorporated in the ending title card where you see a bunch of other character designs.  I would have enjoyed seeing a game that had expanded upon Klara and Belladonna's relationship, what their lives were like before they transformed into gothic automatons, exploring what their interactions would be like with the village beneath the castle.  Overall, I enjoyed this Tim Burton/ Mary Shelly-esque mashup and liked the stylistic choices in the game.  It would have been cool to see this be a longer game!  

I go back and forth when it comes to placing a dollar value on P&C games.  It is ultimately up to each individual to determine if they got their money‚Äôs worth from a game they played.  In this case, I paid a dollar for an hour of game play in a title that I enjoyed for its artistic merit.  Had I paid the full current asking price of $7 for that same hour I would honestly probably have been not thrilled.  That being said if you are a real P&C aficionado with a desire to support the developer, by all means.  This developer‚Äôs only other current title has a very different feel and style than this but based on what I've seen in Belladonna I hope they consider making another P&C game in the future (maybe even a sequel?!?!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043098859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1584878956}
review:
A Frankensteinian romance between two 19th-Century clockwork corpse women is a fascinating premise, but this 1-hour game lacks either the depth or the humour to realise this fully.

The art and design are excellent, reminding somewhat of Deadalic Entertainment's simplified  style. Usable items are also clearly drawn as distinct from their surroundings without sticking out obtrusivley, which as a rarity in adventure games. However, animations are basic to the point of looking like rough proofs. At the time of my playthrough (March 2020), there was also an embarrassing bug where the screen was completely blacked out during the game's climactic cutscene.

Puzzles lack depth, and their solutions are usually spelled out or in one case literally written on the same screen, which is a little unusual for a game that not aimed at the youngest children.

In short, there are glimpses of a solid game here, with an excellent concept and setting that could have yielded some truly disturbing romantic drama, some wild humour or challenging mechanical/biological puzzles, none of which were developed far enough in the end. 

Worth playing as a proof of concept, but limited in every direction. I hope this studio keeps working and manages to find the resources to take their next project to the high level the developers seem capable of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119319611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1570991239}
review: I was so interested in this game when I found it the first time, but it was nothing like I expected it to be. I think it would make a better short story or a short animated movie, but not a game. The art style is simple, but I liked it, the soundtrack is repetitive, but the game is so short that I barely even cared. The price is not so bad for it, but it's too simple for a puzzle game, I finished it in less than an hour (everything above one hour is me leaving the game in the background, trying to collect all trading cards). The puzzles are simple and easy, there was no need to think. It's too lame for a horror game, as well, there aren't really any kind of horror elements, it's just meh. You spend half of the game reading all the random journal notes scattered all over the place. The first part of the story (ca. 40 minutes) is extremely predictable, I already knew it all after finding two notes, the second part (ca. 10 minutes) is complete bs. It turns to a completely different direction that makes zero sense and the characters have zero motivation to do what they do. The ending is a mess and it feels unfinished. I was just kind of annoyed after 30 minutes, especially after I was forced to "solve a puzzle" in a way that I was against. From that point, I felt nothing for the any of the characters, no care, no sympathy whatsoever. The main character is also annoyingly dumb. I found this game weak, flat and disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037077800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1549671621}
review:
Of all the great Gothic Horror stories to come out of Victorian literature, it would appear that the most enduring of these continues to be Mary Shelley's Promethean pastiche, "Frankenstein". As some one who regards Shelley's archetypal Body Horror novel as one of the definitive narratives of my life (consult the work of Karl Jung for more information on that one), then I must admit that I absolutely fell in love with "Belladonna", right from the moment I saw it advertised. 

Carrying the same rich character design featured in "Monkey Island" or "Day of the Tentacle", combined with the same developing in-game plot-line featured in "Whispering Willows", players find themselves thrust into a classically bleak Gothic environment where science and mysticism converge. Dark laboratories, shadowy hallways and the silent finality of the grave. All are presented beautifully herein through painted backdrops and faux-cell animations, suitably accompanied by a deliciously ominous and foreboding cello-centred musical score.  

Admittedly, the game isn't very scary but that is hardly a concern. Those who know the enduring legacy of Shelley's work will appreciate that a greater impact of it's influence was it's ability to adapt to the socio-politics of each period. More specifically, the presence of contemporary gender politics in the game's narrative is highly self-evident and therefore may not be received well by those of a certain persuasion. I shan't get too much into the details here but let's just say that if you're interested in gender politics, then this is definitely a game to look into. 

It's also nice to be playing a female protagonist who isn't just some damsel in distress (I hate when they do that). 

The one criticism of the game is that it is VERY short. I managed to complete "Belladonna" in just under a hour and a half and, while the self-contained nature of the narrative was well put together, it would have been nice for the story not to have concluded at the stage that it did (fingers crossed, therefore, for a sequel). 

In summary, this game is a great pick if it's on sale and is a must for Gothic literature fans. If you want frights, blood and gore however...not so much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034985967', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1485754352}
review:
I really wish I could reccomend this game. I actually enjoyed the game, but I cannot reccomend it because of it's length compared to the price. I have 2.5 hours played, and I have played this game through to completion 3 times. My very first playthrough took me about an hour and a half because I was stuck on one of the puzzles for awhile, but subsequent replays highlight how short the game really is. A game that short just isn't worth the money they are asking at full price. If you can get it on sale, you may enjoy it if you come in with reasonable expectations.  

As a warning for animal lovers about potentially upsetting content: [spoiler]The solution to one of the puzzles involves poisoning (killing) a cat.[/spoiler]

[b]Pros[/b]
---
- Beautiful and unique art style
- Puzzles are fairly well designed with various difficulties, but overall don't feel too hard
- Environmental/background design is really well done
- Representation for sapphic women

[b]Cons[/b]
---
- Too short, especially for the money asked at full price. It is advertised as an "adventure" game, but your adventure has barely begun before it's over.
- The story is a little predictable and cliche, and the best twist was revealed way too early on. [spoiler]At the start of the game you believe you are playing as the inventor's wife as you find all of these notes. It would have been nice if the game stretched that pretense on for a lot longer before you discover that you are playing as the maid.[/spoiler]
- The queer representation isn't the greatest, since one of the characters is morally corrupt, and their relationship has an uneven power dynamic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024812228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1547434630}
review:
[u]Belladonna[/u] is a short gothic beauty: twisted and dark. The puzzles are easy and few and far between. Instead, the game is focused on storytelling, narrative, and visual design. There are a few cutscenes that play out nicely, and the art throughout is simply striking. In a way, [u]Belladonna[/u] is a feminist and gothic take of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein. With a twist at the end. It is a visually striking title, with healthy detail in each level and color that seems to jump out from the screen.

You awaken frightened and disoriented on an experiment table. Your cognitive function seems fine, but you don't exactly feel human. A faint call to Shelley's [i]Frankenstein[/i] is heard ... and alas, as you inspect the bookcase to your side, you encounter a reference to the literature. A subtle ode. Your instincts were right. You press on and exit the laboratory basement to find yourself host to a beautiful medieval castle. As you continue the story you find that your character is intelligent and very witty. Ocassionally she'll break the fourth wall and mock the player for being unable to solve a puzzle. She's curious too. And she has a delightful trait of naming inanimate objects you inspect.

I see [u]Belladonna[/u] as a short reflection on love. Albeit a dark and twisted one. It made me think about how quickly love can bloom when you're young, but also how fast it can fade away with tragedy and neglect. Here, the husband's inability to cope with his son's death resulted in isolation. An isolation from his supposed love that swirled him deeper and deeper into necromancy. And with abuse and neglect, Belladonna, who was also grieving, found new love. Only to be destroyed by his husband's paranoina and sexist ideals of how women ought to think, behave, and act around their husbands.

[b]The one thing I did not enjoy[/b] was that you [i]had[/i] to kill a cat in order to progress. I understand it was done to develop the protagonist's existential crisis. For instance, it posed the question "Am I human if I felt some emotion towards the death of an animal? ... If not, then what am I?" However, I believe the same goal could have been reached without the animal abuse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071375554', 'num_games_owned': 2813, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1540923910}
review:
I love Point&Click games with dark themes and beautiful artwork, Belladonna has that but failed in many other aspects. The story about a corpse girl rising from dead, she doesn't know who she is and how she ended up in a laboratory. With the aid of the scattered journal pages which belong to doctor Wolfram von Trauerschloss and his wife Belladonna, she'll start to piece the story and events together. The ending is weak and sudden in my opinion.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1551909424

You'll wander in an eerie abandon castle, clicking on objects to learn about them. The game has voiceovers but there are lots of reading when you pick the journal pages, which I wished they were voiced since the character herself doesn't say much during the gameplay. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1551911545

The artwork is beautiful, even the game's logo, but there are things happened in the game that left me wondering what the developers were thinking? Even if the main character doesn't have a soul or heart, she doesn't need to kill an animal to prove it! If someone says its ok, it is just a game, but no, when you create something, it means you don't mind this kind of an abuse! And I'm totally against it.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1551909337

The soundtracks were ok, nothing special about it. And the 'forbidden love' might not be everyone's cup of tea and found the reasoning quite weak just like the ending. The puzzles were very easy, and most of them are picking something and combining it with something else to use it. There is also another downside of the game is when you click on something and the character speak, you can't stop her from speaking, she'll keep on talking until she finishes her line, even if you accidentally click on the same item again.

Pros:
+OK soundtracks.
+OK voice over.
+Good artwork.
 
Cons:
-No Steam achievements.
-Short game (Can be finished in an hour).
-No manual save.
-Lack of puzzles.
-No manual save or options for sounds.

I don't recommend it because the story is weak, short and has animal abuse for no real reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048880982', 'num_games_owned': 698, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1530900702}
review:
This game surprised me in a great way. I've been working through bundle games I've had for years and I have some low expectations going in to a lot of them, but Belladonna is worth much more than the fifty cents I bought it for. I wish most games I blindly buy in bundles could give me the same amount of enjoyment. 
Functionally it is a pretty standard point and click adventure, and it's quite short. The "puzzles" have no ridiculous or mind boggling solutions, it's all relatively straightforward, which I appreciated. Graphics and art are a strange mishmash of styles that overall is pretty enjoyable, even when oddly clashing. Keep all this in mind when playing, it's not a AAA game in the slightest, but it has a lot of charm.

 Where the game comes through is the story. It took a lot of familiar tropes and sculpted them into a lovely 2 hour vignette which was actually interesting to play through. There was a pleasant level of strangeness, small but unexpected narrative elements are planted through the game and turn the classic Frankenstein story into something we haven't seen before, and it made me laugh a couple times too. It's got a lot of quirky personality for only 2 hours, and it would make a pretty good movie now that I think about it. If you enjoy the horror genre, especially gothic horror, it's definitely worth your time, especially on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031602014', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1528336203}
review:
Belladonna is a very short game - it'll take maybe two hours if you go really slow - and the "puzzles" offer no actual challenge at all. HOWEVER, it looks nice and stylish, has some good Gothic atmosphere, the writing and voice acting are enjoyable, and while I did of course foresee the broad strokes the plot still threw some minor surprises my way.

The overall experience really reminds me of reading a classic horror short story more than anything else - short, sweet, bracingly macabre and comfortably familiar. The whole thing feels decidedly literary, somehow.

I think the full price tag is much too much, to be honest, but if you can pick it up on sale, say, for half off? Yeah, I would recommend it!

review: Belladonna is a very short but cool point-and-click game. There‚Äôs no complicated puzzles here, just exploration while you gather and use items. The visuals, music, story and voice acting are pretty decent. And there‚Äôs also optional journals to collect and read, and they‚Äôre easy to find. But get it on sale, not because of it‚Äôs quality, but it‚Äôs length. You‚Äôll also need to idle this game for a few hours in order to get all of the trading cards available to drop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201368558', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1527396695}
review:
This gothic point-and-click game tells a wonderful story, one that many games fail to tell in hours of gameplay. I recieved this game as a part of a bundle, and it's probably one of my favorites in the selection. However, due to the short play time amount, it'd be a stretch if I said it was worth the full $6.99 alone. 

Easily one of my favorite short games. The retelling of Mary Shelley's novel, Frankenstein, fell nothing short of wonderful - each letter recieved being entertaining. 

DOWNFALLS, HOWEVER: 
- I feel like you'll have to keep re-entering the game after completion to get all the steam trading cards. 
- Short for $6.99

review:
Pros: 
- Nice graphics/art style
- Solid enough writing 
- Acceptable voice acting, but not great 

Cons: 
- Unoriginal story 
- Way too short 
- Extremely easy, non-complex puzzles 
- Disappointing ending 

There's just not enough here to call this game good. It feels like the first chapter of a longer game. One thing I can say is it's definitely not worth the price. The price is kinda absurd, actually, considering the game is so short. I got it for less than a dollar, and for that price, I'd say go for it if it looks interesting to you. But in any other case, I wouldn't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012507724', 'num_games_owned': 1865, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1519242383}
review:
It's an extremely short point and click game where the story feels incomplete. It's more like chapter 1 of a longer series, yet as far as I can tell, the game isn't episodic. It's just the beginning of a story that's never finished.

On top of that, the engine is rather clumsy (particularly fast-forwarding speech is obnoxious) and the dialogue and writing is very ham-fisted. Belladonna talks like a textbook.

Overall an unpleasant experience with more frustration than entertainment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000888285', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1515717544}
review:
Always been a huge fan of adventure horror, especially games like Sanitarium, The cat lady and Downfall. I was expecting to get a similar experience from this but unfortunately the game lacks every aspect that makes a horror game work. Don't get me wrong the artwork is beautiful and i do somewhat like the music choices that give the game a sort of Frankenstein feel to it. The game is however way too easy and predictable. It took me about 4 script pages to put the plot together, the puzzles required no real ingenuity to figure out and it just wasn't really scary at any point.  Love the genre but if you want to play a horror adventure look for the 3 examples I mentioned earlier. 

PS: Oh and it's waaaaaaay too short

author: {'steamid': '76561197997036304', 'num_games_owned': 3192, 'num_reviews': 459, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1514173243}
review:
Though it's a short game, what it makes up for in length is has some quality in classic gothic horror, along with the final outcome that can be both understood, yet also terrified at the idea.

It clearly borrows elements of Frankenstein and plays with the ideas of reanimating the dead through the use of technology and asks what might be missing if one were reanimated, a question that has been asked many times in many different ways, but it's still a fun concept to play with. The ending somewhat comes off as if you are really villains, but ones you can understand the motivation of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153599813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1514096308}
review: Short, but ultimately adorable. Pretty simple old-school point and click play. Combine Thing A with Thing B to make Thing AB to fetch Thing C. If you're looking for a challenging game, this is not it. The adventuring is mostly to keep you entertained while you learn the story. Like an interactive fiction game, only with stuff to do and not nearly as amateurish as they usually are. Totally worth buying on sale. Also, without getting spoilery, +100 grrlpower points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166044399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1516172482}

author: {'steamid': '76561198138717361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1513400503}
review:
It's a pretty good game that's welcoming to those new to the point and click genre. The plot is heavily inspired by Mary Shelly's 'Frankenstein' mixed in with some gothic romance and tragedy. The puzzles are fairly easy and logical, and the plot is quite predictable. Nevertheless, I enjoyed the overall experience and finished it in one sitting. Despite being able to predict the outcome of the plot within just a few rooms, I enjoyed the ride and found the story intriguing. My only complaints are the slow walking speed and tiny text for the journal entries.

+Important tip - Buy this on sale. 
I liked this game, but I don't think the price justifies the short game time. The voice acting and art is of quality though so I think it ultimately depends on if you want to support to devs and whatnot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201329239', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1509922355}
review:
This is a game you play for the story. The writing is superb, and very engaging. I liked the complex characters and the moral ambguity between all of their motivations This is a game that's hard to finish because of the sheer wrongness of some of the things you do and other characters do. I like that in a game. I like my mind to be challenged. I like to see characters with flawed morals and personality that so deeply contradict my own while still being engaging and sensical. This is what true horror should be, something that unsettles and disurbs you.

The gameplay though... lol, even when it comes to point and clicks, this is minimalistic. This is not a "fun" game, it's a pretty (very, very pretty) game that you play as a vessel to enjoy an interesting story. I didn't expect it to be anything more than a walking simulator, gameplay-wise, so I was entirely satisfied with the gameplay. Only caveat would be that the actually walking is incredibly slow, so backtracking is a bt tedious, but the game is simple enough that it's not too much of a bother. The slow pace helps set the mood, anyway.

 For what it is, it's really great, though. The plot and the puzzles are all solid and logical, everything is explained astoundingly well.

I wouldn't buy it for full price, but I'd definitely give this a try if you can get it for cheap and would like to enjoy a game just for it's story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198376317844', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1509450807}
review:
Belladonna is a good game with really beautiful art, almost like playing a modern-day cartoon; however, the story itself, is certainly not for kids.  The game is not overly dark or gruesome but story-wise, meant to be played for mature audiences only.

The biggest knock on the game is the price tag based on the length to complete the game.  This game can be completed within a 1 hour and 30 minutes.  Other than that, the game itself is really nicely done even in its simplicity.

There are a couple of gameplay elements in this game that may be considered a negative but should be considered as a positive.  

First, this game is a point-and-click game and the player interacts with objects and items like any point-and-click game.  Things you pick up aren‚Äôt many so it‚Äôs more limited and simple compared to other games.  This is a good thing.  In other point-and-click games, sometimes picking up objects are non-sensical and applying them doesn‚Äôt relate to the story.  It‚Äôs just a means to an end in progressing the game.  Also, collecting, combining and applying random items can be a common frustration in a point-and-click game.  In Belladonna, the items collected are far and few and sometimes they make sense.  This gets rid of frustration and allows the player to stay focused on the story while being engaged with a bit of gameplay.

Secondly, constant reading can feel boring and tedious.  If you play Belladonna, there will be a lot of reading; thankfully, the reading of journals not only bring context to the story but also purpose.  The journal entries bring light to what happened and the more you read, the more you are invested to collect all entries to see how it ends.

It‚Äôs a good game and worth a try for those who enjoy point-and-click adventure games

author: {'steamid': '76561198185767254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1509155884}
review:
BELLADONNA T H I C C
Positives
+ Voice acting does its job; its decent but nothing special
+Art is pretty good
+Easy baby puzzles
Negatives
-Maybe its just me but I don't think that Kelena's voice actor did her justice, she sounds like a teenage girl or a child. 

-Again, its just me, but I think that Kelena's avatar should have more movements rather than walking to the side and her front. I think it would do a better feel for making her more lifelike. I noticed at times when she was distressed, there was no emotion on her face to portray it. I understand that she's a undead body but she can still have emotions, Hell even Major Makoto from Ghost in the shell had more expressions than this girl does. It wouldn't be so bad either if she had some idle animations rather than standing there and blinking.

-Character development is very rushed and can be emotionless at times. All of the characters have one or two motivations and are very linear. Especially Belladonna, after she 'awoke' she sent out to do her 'duty' and then reunite with her 'lover' but then had a crazy idea to continue the evil work her husband has done. It makes no sense for her to do that and no where in the story hints that she would. 
-The story isn't really that unique. Not much stands out other than what the characters look like.

review:
Tags: Adventure - P&C - Point&Click
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Showcase grade/demo grade Unity Engine point&click adventure game without resolution options. Forgettable. Amateur voice acting.

Its a decent miniature sized experience with very light user interface, thin puzzles, and low amount of content but decent flavor, with an eye catching art style and a simple starting premisce that hooks you early.

It has about the same level of polish as you'd expect to see in something like "The Silent Age". Except the silent age has a great deal more puzzle complexity, adds a navigation gimmick and fleshens out its setting better. This feels improvised, charming, lower ambitions and and short lived in comparison. Few puzzles are there make sense, interface is extremely streamlined with a simple "interact with hotspot" mechanic and a simple inventory management. The voice acting was a nice touch, but the valley girl robot is an odd combination that might not had been the best combination of tones.

review:
The puzzles are meh ("Get Key from right next to door, Use key on that door"), you run around collecting journal pages that contain the story in them, but I enjoyed that story a fair bit.  Your protagonist has amnesia, and you spend a while wondering which of the people you are and who made you the way you are, and there's a curveball or two.  I wish the protagonist walked faster, spoke faster, or was less long-winded in narrative descriptions of things.

Still though, short and sweet.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989914240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1504137641}
review:
First off, I LOVE point and click games.  So, I'll admit to being a little biased towards anything that breathes a little life into my favorite genre (no pun intended...oh who am I trying to fool - totally intended..)

With that being said, there were a lot of things I really liked about this game:  art style, music, plot - overall atmosphere was great.  I'm hoping that they add more to this game at some point, I would totally buy some expanded DLC or a sequel.

Now...the downside: 
For the price, it is too short and very, VERY simple when it comes to puzzles.  The only reason I spent slightly over an hour on it was that I stopped to give our cat his medicine partway through; and speaking of cats I spent about 10 min trying to find an alternative solution to a puzzle involving a cat ( [spoiler] come on guys, you really didnt have to kill it [/spoiler] )....so yeah, you could probably shave a good 15-20 min off my time as far as gameplay goes.  

So overall - if you are new to the point and click genre or think you suck at puzzles this might be the ego boost you're looking for.  If you love games like this absolutely get it on sale - its a good experience but not at $7 for 30-40 minutes of gameplay.

And Developers: if you would fix the fonts in the diary entries, that would be fabulous :) I like that they are different but they really are hard to read at that size.  I thought at first it was just me, I have been playing games for over 40 years and my eyes arent what they used to be...but there are people half my age having a few issues there too sooooo....there's that...

review:
This is as simple as it gets for a point-and-click. The puzzles are easy. If you've ever played any adventure game before, this will be a breeze.

The art style is okay. It's got a fun look, but nothing to amazing.

As for the navigation, it's really frustrating moving from room to room. If you click on the wrong thing, you'll have to do a lot more clicking to go through the mountains of dialogue. 

The high point is the story. It's very rare for a game like this to explore such intriguing themes. I was hoping we'd explore the relationships a little bit more. Sadly, the ending is a letdown, and we don't get a satisfying conclusion.

Overall: 2/5

review: Belladonna is short and sweet. Fans of gothic style horror, or Tim Burton (specifically Edward Scissorhands) will find the atmosphere intoxicating and the aesthetic pleasing. Belladonna is an indie game that not everyone will appreciate. It deals with some fairly heavy subjects like adultery, objectification of women, what it means to be alive, and human reproduction. If the trailer video interests you I suggest you give this game a shot. Don't plan on playing for an extended period of time however as the game can be completed in as little as an hour or 1 hour 30 minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098455928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1503543733}
review:
A very average point-and-click game. I completed it in under an hour and a half.

The good:
++ The beginning of the story was interesting. Trying to figure out your current situation and what had happened and starting to explore the castle.
++ The art design was pretty good.
++ The voice acting was alright.

The bad:
-- Increadibly short. The castle was tiny. Should have made it larger with more exploration.
-- Shortly after the beginning, it was easy to figure out everything, so the twist/revelation wasn't unexpected. Then the story just leads into an unsatisfying ending. The game could have kept going past the ending -- it just seemed like one chapter of a story that could have had more twists in the future.
-- What little animation there was was not good.

Overall, I'd rate is 5/10, mediocre. This game could have been quite good, but sadly it just wasn't realized past a very basic plot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078288325', 'num_games_owned': 2748, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1494074839}
review:
It's a (very) short Point & Click adventure game with a Frankenstein-like story.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Nice graphic art
[*]Good voice acting
[*]Overall polished (engine and UI)
[*]Quality ambient soundtrack
[*]Interesting story
[/list]
[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Too easy (can be suitable for persons who never played a Point & Click adventure game)
[*]Too short (I finished it in 1h30, then had to run the game in background to drop the remaining trading cards.)
[*]Lack of video and sound option (Launch in Fullscreen HD)
[*]Maybe too much text to read (the diary pages that you find all along)
[*]Currently overpriced in my opinion, even if the dev has made undeniable efforts to achieve a polished quality product, there are lot of Point & Click Adventure games that are more interesting for cheaper.
[/list]
I finally recommend it for the story and the overall quality, but when on sale or in a bundle. 6.5/10

review:
This is not a bad game, nor is it a good game.

To give it a thumbs up would be to ignore its brevity, its miniscule puzzles, and its shoddy voice acting.

TLDR; Play it if you get it in a bundle, but don't buy it alone.
