review:
"Belladonna" ist ein kurzes, stilsicheres Point-and-Click-Adventure.

Wir erwachen in einem merkw√ºrdigen Labor. Unser Ged√§chtnis ist ausgel√∂scht. Offenbar sind wir eine schlanke junge Frau mit einer Glatze und einem Aufziehmechanismus, der direkt durch unseren Kopf f√ºhrt. So weit, so Frankenstein.

Also schleichen wir durch die R√§ume des gruseligen Anwesens und versuchen zu ergr√ºnden, was die Hintergr√ºnde unserer Situation und Existenz sein m√∂gen. Daf√ºr finden wir immer wieder einzelne Seiten, die Teile der Geschichte enth√ºllen. 

Mechanisch befinden wir uns im klassischen Point-and-Click. In Screens k√∂nnen wir Gegenst√§nde betrachten, einige aufnehmen, um sie zu kombinieren oder in anderen Screens einzusetzen. Gute, alte Hausmannskost also. Mit Inventar.

Die Grafik ist erstaunlich stilsicher, schafft es mit seinem klaren Comicstil das Genre gekonnt zu treffen und mit Niveau zu unterhalten. Ebenso gekonnt erweist sich die talentierte englischsprachige Sprecherin in den vertonten Passagen. Ihre Haltungen spiegeln die intelligente, manchesmal zu ironischem Phlegma neigende Figur.

Und das ist das Erstaunliche und die eigentliche St√§rke von "Belladonna". Im Gegensatz zum tumben Frankenstein einer Mary Shelly ist hier der Hauptcharakter intelligent, reflektiert und auch humorf√§hig, trotz oder gerade wegen der durchs Hirn getriebenen Drehschraube. Auch die Geschichte ist gekonnt erz√§hlt und funktioniert wie eine Short Story.

Das gr√∂√üte Problem ist allerdings der Umfang, der durch das abrupte Ende und die sehr einfachen R√§tsel auch nicht gerade zunimmt. Auch wenn man alle Zettel liest, kann man in 90 Minuten durch sein. Aber besser knackig und gut als umfangreich und langweilig. Auch in diesem Punkt ist "Belladonna" eine bella donna.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
8/10 Atmosph√§re
8/10 Story
7/10 Grafik
8/10 Sound
7/10 Spielmechanik
5/10 Balancing
8/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Lieber ein schnelles Ende mit Schrecken als ein schneller Schrecken ohne Ende.

[h1][b]7/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198095423596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1486295449}
review:
Oh dear, oh dear. 
This is one of those games that really needs a "meh" button. I did decide to recommend it in the end, but if I were you I'd wait for the next sale. It's not a bad game, but it's pretty expensive for what it is - namely more of a slightly interactive short story.

-Technical Stuffs-
Runs fine. No crashes, no bugs.

-Visuals-
The art style is interesting and appealing, but also pretty rough in places. It's a visually pretty well designed game, though, and everything fits together quite nicely. There's a nice sort of coherence to the entire thing, also regarding the color choices. I like 2D games with a bit of character, so I'm willing to let it slide if the style occasionally went from "stylized and painterly" to "pretty sketch-y, if you know what I mean". 

-Audio-
The soundtrack was pretty decent and matched the game well, but it's not completely mindblowing or anything, either. The main character was pretty well voiced (in a characteristically rough-around-the-edges kinda way), the rest of the voice acting was... okay? I guess?

-Gameplay-
You click on stuff, which pretty much works as well as you'd expect it to - namely pretty well, if you're fond of clicking on stuff. On the downside, there's really not much to do except for clicking on stuff. The game is extremely linear, and extremely easy. There are some very, very minor puzzles, but I never even had to stop and think.

-Story 'n Stuff-
There are two big plot twists, one I (and pretty much everyone else) knew about and one I saw coming from a mile off. There were some small things I didn't see coming, too, which was neat. Not quite sure what to think about that ending, though - IMO it was either five minutes too long, or a few hours too short, but the game ending where it does feels a bit odd.

-Conclusion-
I enjoyed the game quite a bit, it was half cute and half pretty thought-provoking and it's certainly quite different. Alas, once you've played through it, you've pretty much seen it all, which leaves you with... oh, around an hour or so of playtime and no reason to go back and play it again. As I mentioned, the full price is fairly expensive for an hour of playtime. Not egregiously so, not by any means, but still. Then again, this is a tiny, tiny indie game made by a tiny, tiny team, so I'm willing to cut the creator(s)* some slack.
I do recommend this game on sale. If you can get it for cheap, get it. If it's worth the money at full price depends on your disposable income - if those seven bucks are a decent chunk of money for you, you should probably pass and go for something with more replay value, but if you've got money to spend... Belladonna is not a bad game by any means.

[spoiler]That said, I really hope they re-animated that cat after they were done with that... other... thing. I mean... sheesh, girl, was that really necessary?[/spoiler]

*read as: voice actress, music person and the guy who did everything else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015003424', 'num_games_owned': 1489, 'num_reviews': 265, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1485485998}
review: Belladonna is an odd game. Things start off well enough, with a mystery and an appealing art style. However, as the play continues, it soon becomes obvious that the scenic designer has forgotten to finish the sets, the screenwriter left the script to be written by his curious teenage daughter, and the director is shouting out spoilers from behind the curtain. The gothic castle consists of a couple tiny rooms, the initially dark story soon throws all of that out the window and ends in a puzzlingly cheery end-title screen reminiscent of the game covers from the 90's (think Commander Keen) that looks extremely out of place, and the point-and-click adventure boils down to the game telling the player exactly what and where to use. The entire ordeal is over in an hour, with 3 more hours of idling for cards, and quite frankly you'd be far better off going to the library and checking out a copy of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997328781', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1484944090}
review:
Belladonna is a point-and-click adventure game with a gothic twist. Scratch that; Belladonna is a point-and-click adventure game that echoes M. W. Shelley and tells a dark but fun story without descending into Adventure Game Logic.

Belladonna isn't difficult. There's maybe an hour an a half of content here, give or take, and the puzzles are straighforward and perfectly logical. So, as an Adventure Game, it's unremarkable and not at all frustrating.

Where it really shines, though, is in the voice acting and the art. It is beautiful and charming in its Gothic-Horror appeal. It never even comes close to being scary, but then much classic Gothic horror just isn't. Neither of the gothic horror stories it seems to draw most strongly from (Carmilla and Frankenstein) are especially scary - but they deal in unsettling concepts. 

That's something that makes Belladonna special. It's a horror story and a gothic romance, beautifully put together into a package that will occupy you about as long as a movie would. It's frankly just a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082874363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1493064169}
review:
You are a female Frankenstein creation, born into an adult body with full language skills and articulation but no memories of your previous life as a human. There are some notes scattered throughout that tell pieces of the story of your creator, which was far from a happy one. With some effort, you eventually can escape your "birth chamber"...and that's when things really get interesting. Such is the basic setup of Belladonna and to reveal too many more specifics would be a disservice.

Okay, let's get a few things out of the way first. One, this is not a long game to play. It took me a little over an hour to make my way though the whole story, there are no side activities and the overall area you're playing in is very contained. Two, the puzzle-solving is logical but extremely basic. I would be very surprised if a player who has made it through the likes of the classic Sierra or Lucasarts series of adventure games didn't have an idea what to do just through careful examination and deductive reasoning (to say nothing of your player character's own observations in the rare event that you are stuck). Indeed, had I not purchased this for an extreme discount during the Winter Sale this past year, I would feel extremely cheated by such features.

So why am I giving this game a thumbs up? Because, as little as it does overall, it does those few things so right as to make the experience memorable. I realize how many modern players object to reading letters as opposed to hearing them given a voiceover but the story the letters you find weave a tale that's worth the VERY few minutes you need to spend reading them. While there are plenty of playful references to Poe and Young Frankenstein as well as surprisingly insightful observations from your player character that emphasizes her innocence, the overall story is the real winner. It is nothing less than the most subversive take on Frankenstein that I have ever seen (and I am a hardcore fan of all things Frankenstein) with a feminist slant that makes me wish the game had lasted a little longer.

If you are willing to overlook the flaws I've already noted, I can promise that this video-game-as-short-story is VERY worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018022182', 'num_games_owned': 596, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1524809160}
review:
I would definitely recommend that people play this game, but only if they get it on sale. I think I paid, like, 15 cents for it during the fall? While it's an amazing game and I loved it, it's definitely not worth $6.99. It's quite a short game. As you can tell by my hours on record, I literally beat it all in 1 hour. I walked everywhere and double checked to ensure I did everything and still beat it in an hour. Others have beat it in less time. For me, I just took my sweet time so I could enjoy the game, which I would definitely suggest, since it's worth playing. 

That being said, if you skip over the price and the playtime length, it's  still quite awesome, simply for the enjoyment factor and the fact that it's definitely unique in comparison to other games. 

This game had an interesting premise to it and odd art. That's what drew me in. I love creepy and weird things like this, plus it's a point-n-click game, so it's even cooler, since I'm a huge fan of those types of games. It gave me the same eerie vibes that the game "Harvester" (Another great point-n-click game that I grew up playing and still love) gave me- a combination of Tim Burton and Guillermo Del Toro. The plot is interesting and I love getting back story and whatnot as you go along. Couple it with the strange music and it's definitely a great game. 

Aside from the price and play time, my only real complaint is about the ending.

*SPOILERS*

It abruptly ended and just felt too short and unepic. I did like the ending image, though.

*END OF SPOILERS*

Overall, I would recommend this game. Just, not at full price.

review:
Purchased during Steam Fall 2016 Sale for 69¬¢, and [b]ONLY AT THAT PRICE[/b]  would I give a [i]RECOMMENDED[/i] vote.  If one penny, pence, or peso more than that, and I'd say wait for a sale, or simply put your money back in your pocket. 6.99 euros, dollars, etc. is a bad joke.

The story (do not confuse this with 'a game') IMO is a decent but VERY Short visual novel / point and click with zero choices, other than selecting the questions you are required to ask at only one point in the story. The number of hours reflected above represent the eternity spent waiting for the 7 cards to drop, while actual playtime was barely 1-1.5 hours max.

PROS: The story is fairly interesting while being just too short. For what it is, I think it is well done and it did keep my interest. The artwork is ok, and the voice acting was nice. The click zones for items collected were good, and crafting was easy.

CONS: 1) Dev has stated that no Achievements will be coming for Belladonna - PERIOD (ok, fair enough); 2) BUT, the HUGE number of Trading Cards (13) are grossly disproportionate to the terribly small number of items that will drop (i.e. 3 backgrounds ONLY) - Really!!! Reeks of a cash-grab IMO. 
[u]Side-note: the ARTWORK on the Trading Cards is Amazing!! The 'artwork' on the Backgrounds look like it was done by a child.[/u] 
Did I mention?! CASH GRAB !! At least gamers can try to sell the 3¬¢ cards, but good luck with that since the seller to buyer ratio is around 10:1 ....YMMV.

Overall 6/10 ......... Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561198063048114', 'num_games_owned': 2657, 'num_reviews': 540, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1482542123}
review:
Despite the fact that this game is short and a little too easy for those who eat adventure games for breakfast, "Belladonna" has a very unique style, it looks pretty and it's easy to get attached to the main character - she's nor good nor evil and that adds some depth to the overall feeling.

Ah, and one other thing - the developer himself wrote somewhere on his website that his work is highly influenced not only by other video games, but also by literature. I can say that it really feels, especially while reading the pages torn from "Belladonna's" characters diaries. 

All in all, i can highly recommend this game for people who value atmosphere, characters and story in each game. And those, who like only long and/or hard puzzle adventures might as well look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067204970', 'num_games_owned': 2128, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1482420581}
review:
Belladonna is a short point and click game that is clearly inspired by the famous Frankenstein series. In my opinion I see this game as charming and interesting with nicely drawn environments. The puzzles seem very simple and straightforward with the main character even sometimes telling you what you need or where to go however this is not necessarily a bad thing. Because of the puzzles' simplicity it keeps the game moving forward and the story going. The notes give a good sense of story and even though it is a beautiful one it can be predictable as I drew two conclusions with one of them being correct in the end.
The graphics of the cutsene in the bedroom looks strange and out of place. I did not see the reason to even have that cutscene.

PROS:
¬¨Appealing art style to the game and story
¬¨Interesting story
¬¨A good way to relax for an hour
¬¨Main character with interesting dialogue (inspect everything you can, you won't regret it)

CONS:
¬¨It is very SHORT. The game took me 1.5 hours to complete. This was due to me not hurrying and reading all of the notes carefully. The gameplay itself is only about an hour long. This is not good when the game itself costs ¬£4.99. With this price you would expect the game to be longer.

OVERALL, I think that this game is worth trying as it provides a good story and a nice artstyle. However, try to get this game when it is on SALE. The price that the game currently is on is too much for the length of the game but with a sale it is worth it. I got my own copy from a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971341065', 'num_games_owned': 3377, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1454362996}
review:
Belladonna is a very stylish point and click adventure with an interesting story. The key feature here is the story and atmosphere, although be warned the main bulk of the story is divulged in extensive diary entries and letters you find lying around as you progress through the story, there are very few direct interactions between the three main characters - you are mostly learning about their past and how things turned out as they did.

In terms of gameplay there isn't much here, you wander about the castle solving minor point and click item fetch/search quests and trivial puzzle solving sections, mostly the game is an interactive base for the story to be told and it is all very linear, so little replayability here. This isn't that uncommon for a point and click adventure of course.

Overall this is worth playing through, it is not like it will take you too long, and has a nice dark gothic story and atmosphere but don't expect too much in terms of actual game to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267393126', 'num_games_owned': 1360, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1504781952}
review:
Belladonna is an incredibly beautiful and well written story, the puzzles perhaps could have been more difficult, however I doubt that was the focus of this game

The characters are all individually interesting, and the playable character is adorable and lively, she makes me want to interact with every object over and over again just in case she has another comment to make

My only true complaint is that this game feels as if it should be longer, the ending is rather abrupt and it just sounds and looks like there was meant to be more story

I was very interested in [spoiler] how Belladona and Karla's relationship would develop. There is and was such a complete imbalance of power between them, and considering the ending image, I doubt that would have changed, but I would have liked to see them talking more about themselves and each other, and rectifying the damage the Karla's lost memories would have caused. Did Karla ever remember, or did she develop into a new person without them [/spoiler] I'm left feeling like I'm 3/4 of the way through the book and find that the rest has been ripped out

All in all, this is probably one of my favourite games, even if I'm feeling unfulfilled by it, a good game is one that has you wanting more of it so I can appreciate that

review:
This is kind of a hard one to review. I like the gameplay and art style. It's about as long as you want it to be. The price is appropiate. What puts me on the fence a bit is the story, which I will try to discuss without spoilers.

The story reminds me of reading the book The Invisible Man. It's a good book, but you don't like any of the characters. This game is the same way. As you progress through the game, you find out things about all of the characters which make you lose any kind of respect or empathy you could have for them. While it's certainly possible to create a good, well written story about a bunch of terrible people (Always Sunny in Philadelphia, anyone?) it makes it hard to enjoy an interactive experience when you don't like the character you're controlling. I realize this might be a minor spoiler, but I think I might have been able to enjoy the game more knowing this in advance.

review:

I could feel it tried to be mysterious and twisted, but it's nothing but a wannabe in the end. You don't need to be born Sherlock in order to figure out the whole plot right from the beginning. The tiny text discouraged me from reading all the letters and I started skipping eventually. No puzzles or whatsoever, just follow the straight line and you'll be fine. Nice artwork, cyberpunk-ish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070591452', 'num_games_owned': 1415, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1467315977}
review:
Atmospheric little Indie point and click. And by little i mean a game that can be completed in an hour, at first time. There isn't achievements to get, but there are cards. If point and click is your preferred genre, then this is a good addition to your library. But for people who want a quality point and click, there are much better alternatives for random point and click gaming moments.

Puzzles are pretty easy, the main emphasis in this game lies in the story, and it's pretty mediocre. You can easily guess the ending halfway through the game. And at times seems like the devs were going for different endings, but for some reason didn't. There were couple pretty clear points where you, as the main character was supposed to make choices. It wuold have added replayability to this otherwise linear point and click adventure.

It's a cool, bug free game thats fun to play through once. But not really worth many euros since you get only about an hour of linear playing, best to get with a bundle. I don't even have much to say about this game :D I just don't know what to say. It's pretty neutral in my eyes. 
My thumbs up is mainly to give a positive score, since it isn't a bad game, it isn't especially dull actually. This game just exists. One hour of fun, and that's about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992794647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1478804693}
review: I'd reccommend Belladonna only on sale, for it only had about an hour of gameplay. Despite the puzzles being fairly simple and the limited locations, it was great in theme and atmosphere for me. The soundtrack and voice acting is lovely, and I found myself engrossed in the story. If only it was a prequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276299946', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1478292664}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198259697499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1484036521}
review:
I'm recommending this game under the guise that you only buy it when on sale.
Overall, Belladonna is pretty good point-and-click story with just enough what-the-heck to keep it interesting.
It is relatively short and the ending is a little too feel-good, let's-wrap-this-up-with-a-happy-love-bow-in-the-last-ten-minutes-of-the-game.
But hey, [spoiler] it's got lesbians [/spoiler]. I can never really discount a game for having that.

Puzzles aren't too taxing and you don't really spend more than 5 minutes having to think up an answer. While this is a plus in any game, for a game that is as short as Belladonna, I maybe would have liked something a tad more trying.

--
This is added after I spent several more hours trying to get card drops so, first off, disregard the time on by my name. My original run through of this game took me 40 minutes.
Another thing I would like to add is, after I sat here and played the game several more times to receive card drops, I realized just how problematic this game is in general.

Honestly, it was just a game I sort of bought real cheap on sale, played real fast, then forgot about until I realized I had seven more card drops avaliable.
Through my second and third playthrough of the game, I started really reading the notes of that are left behind and listening to the converations Klara has with herself and Belladonna and the game is actually pretty disconcerting.

[spoiler] At one point, both Klara and Belladonna acknowledge that they no longer have concern for lives around them and feel no mercy towards killing things, and Belladonna literally just is all like 'it's fine; we're dead anyways so we should have to care about living people.' [/spoiler]

Just... some of the things said are really disturbing and, it's layered with pretty (yet sometimes grotesque) art and cute phrases from Klara.

I still wouldn't say you should buy this game for anything more than **maybe** $3, but the more I played it the more I actually ended up liking it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201996733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1478042568}
review: Belladonna is an old school point & click game with decent plot and pleasant graphics. It's easy and short (I don't like long and difficult games so that's alright to me) but for 0,69 euros discounted price it's absolutely worth it. The perfect game to be played on Halloween eve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061666318', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1478113321}
review:
Short but very climatic. As it last only 1hour it's not worth 7EUR. But I've got it on Halloween sale for 0.69 and I don't regret it. 
If you like visual novels with little puzzle it's a game for you :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197991657927', 'num_games_owned': 1410, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1477919203}
review: A very short and simple point and click adventure based on Frankenstien and The Bride of Frankenstien. The puzzles are simple and logical which means that players will have little trouble in completing the game in a single sitting of an hour and a half to two hours. It doesn't really add any new themes or questions to the original works but rather presents the same ones in another format. For this reason I can't really recommend it at its full price but it MIGHT be worth picking up on sale for point and click lovers despite its shortness. For me, however, it is too linear, short, and ultimately, unfulfilling.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969189043', 'num_games_owned': 5887, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1477700536}

[u]The bad[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198004572694', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1472052467}
review:
This is a mostly solid short story. The artwork was nice and the flow of the game was good.

Its is a short game that focuses more on the story rather than typical adventure point and click stuff.  The traditional PnC adventure puzzles were short and simple, mostly due to being practical.

Only major complaint was the lack of audio/video controls. The game scaled well, but lack of audio controls is not acceptable.

Anyway, this is a decent stocking stuffer and a good way to support an indie company.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207945752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1471801633}
review:
So basically this game's not bad, also enjoyable and has a great soundtrack. If you like something more macabre, Frankenstein themed you will totally dig this. The art style is pretty decent and the character design itself is not bad. But don't expect too much. You'll enjoy it, but don't expect too much because:
-It's rather short (took me about a bit more than an hour just because I was too dumb to find some items) ) and you get those journal pages pretty frequent, a bit too fast for me. The long entries kinda try building up a story but for my taste too fast, without getting to know the different characters too much aka no hard feels
-Gameplay is rather straight, you don't need to conclude much and you can find items pretty easily (if you're not blind like me) and there was no moment where I really had to think about it. Too bad, I always like grinding my own gears a bit more in those kind of games. 
-Story had potential but ended kinda flat 

Don't get me wrong I still enjoyed it for what it is and the small amount of people working on it, just don't get your hopes too high

author: {'steamid': '76561197999217003', 'num_games_owned': 2570, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1451462096}
review:
[h1]THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | *2* 3] = ~62% (50%-75%)[/h1]

Belladonna strongly focuses on the story, not at all on the gameplay (hence the simple point&click actions required, no actual puzzles), which indeed translates to low replay value and also spoiler-sensitivity, but I had a good time with the game. My play-through took about 100+ minutes that I don't regret in the least. But they are over now. Mind that when you decide to get the game.

I saw complaints here about length vs asking-price (‚Ç¨7), and I do have to agree with those. 3‚Ç¨ or less would be well measured. (Sorry, creator, but I look at it from the consumer side. I can imagine what this feels like, I've been on the other side of the fence, too.) I got the game for practically no cash because it came in a bundle.

I played the game on Window 10 without issues or special settings.

The store page mentions trading cards. I didn't get any, but another review is saying that leaving the game on for a few more hours drops the cards.



[h1]META[/h1]

I personally don't care about cards, I'm just mentioning this aspect so that you know. (I didn't even care about cards before I entirely stopped using the market when Valve introduced those [i]absolutely ridiculous[/i] limitations. Security is one thing, but enforcing (metaphorically) a three levels deep recursion of "Are you [really] sure?" dialogs whenever I throw a 10ct article on the market is quite another. It was ok before, but now it's an insult.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030629945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1469127860}
review:
[h1]Tinkerbelladonna & Blitzen[/h1]

Creepy and charming,  [I]Belladonna[/I] is a short, but fantastically macabre point-and-click story by [b]Neckbolt[/b], the development studio of Niklas Hallin. Yes, one guy did the whole thing (minus voice-acting and music), which is perfectly impressive.

The tale seems famililar, but with clever misdirects and surprises that left me wanting two things:
[olist]
[*]A sequel
[*]A courageous Kara cosplayer
[/olist]

[u]This game is for you if[/u]
[list]
[*]You enjoy undead love triangles
[*]You like to support indie developers
[*]You're curious what a person can accomplish when they stop [I]playing[/I] games and start [I]making[/I] them
[*]You prefer straightforward point-and-clickers instead of ones requiring a walkthrough
[*]You're comfortable with small-animal murder, corpse mutilation, and allusions to necrophilia
[*]You ever wondered what Frankenstein's monster could do if he buckled down and really applied himself
[/list]

PS. You'll likely finish this game in an hour (give or take), but will need to leave it running to unlock all the gorgeous trading cards. They're worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198278707247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1467575992}
review:
I was really excited for this game because the artstyle promised so much, and I think that's the biggest disapointment of this whole experience. 

Granted, the story and concept still hold proimse. If there was a larger team with a bit more experience and possibly a better budget, I think this game could be really engaging. Unfortunately the dialouge and voice acting in this left much to be desired. That being said, what do you really expect for a game set at this price? It's a fun way to kill an hour or so, but realise what you're getting into with this price tag before getting your hopes too high.

review:
Belladonna is a female protagonist point and click adventure, with a (lesbian?) Frankenstein theme. 
The puzzles are very easy and straightforward object manipulation, the story is told in notes which you find laying about in the rooms. The game is well made, but lasts only about an hour.
There is no options screen, and you can't change the audio or anything.
As it is well made, it is a pleasure to play, however because it is also a very short pleasure, you should only purchase it at very low price (I got my copy at about ‚Ç¨0.25 part of a flash bundle sale)
Belladonna, my first impression video, and as it happens also a full walkthrough:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4LPGSvNsWYQ
As usual pics on my fb.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152700505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1467237389}
review:
Wow. This was ... different from what I expected.
First of all, I didn't expect a long game, and I didn't get one - but this really IS fairly short, I finished it in about 70 minutes including going back and forth because I somehow overlooked some of the rather obvious items.
Which is the second point I want to bring up: it really is easy. You rarely have to look twice to find things and there is no abundance of detail to distract you from finding what you need. Also, I figured the story - told in journey entries - out halfway into the game.
But still, I liked it very much.
The protagonist has a quite strange yet cute sense of humour that doesn't really fit with the dark atmosphere and almost menacing music, but it doesn't mess things up, either. (And the voice actress is great, besides having a very nice voice.)
Beautiful story, nicely told and building up tension - to a point, where things start dawning on you. But hey. Also, there IS a little twist in the end.
And that credit graphic - brilliant.
So I would suggest you scrape that price together and get it. It's a nice distraction if you're feeling gothic-y on evenings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198308696833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1494005395}
review:
First and foremost, Belladonna is a very, very short and simple game. Theres no challenge and I don't think it's worth it at full price, that said, if you purchase it in the sales like I did, it can be very enjoyable.
The art is stylish and atmospheric, the voice acting for the most part is good, and the story is solid (although lacks faith in the players ability to infer the plot for themselves) and it is overall a very nice little boredom-killer.
I would be excited for a sequel so long as it were longer and more challenging.
--Do get it in the sales if bored, give it a miss at full-price.

review:
At the first glance Belladonna looks promising. The art style is pretty, although I disliked the movement of the female protagonist. But very soon I discovered that the items that you can interact with are very few. The amount of items you can pick up to combine or puzzle with are maybe ten pieces. The story is a bit weird, not bad, but it isn't exactly 'told'. Almost the whole thing is written on journal pages which you have to find throughout the game. So literally, half of the game you are just reading.

Biggest bummer is that the game is way too short. I finished it in about one hour and a half, but I really needed to go the bathroom in the meantime so make that one hour in total. And that's without a quick travel option, an option that is missed. The game really doesn't have any more environments than the screenshots above. I finished it so fast that I didn't even get one trading card. Belladonna is a game which is easy to forget. Pity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024090261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1466934858}
review:
[b]Pros and Cons list at the bottom of the review.[/b]

Belladonna is a decent point-and-click adventure, and it's low price tag makes it easier to recommend. 

The story is not exactly inspired, somewhat of a generic "Frankenstein's Monster" story, but it is passable. About halfway through the game you will likely have guessed the rest of the plot. 

The game itself is only about 75-90 minutes long, depending on how fast you read and how much backtracking you have to do to grab items you didn't see the first time. Luckily, the game levels are not very large, so backtracking isn't much of a pain. The puzzles themselves are not too bad, I had an easier time with this game than some other point-and-click's where what you have to do next is very obscure. 

The writing and voice acting are somewhat amateurish, though for the most part the journals you will read throughout the game were not too badly written. The main character's voice just sounded off to me, more like a young boy than a young woman's. 

The graphics and aesthetics in the game are likely the best part of the game, and I thought everything was beautifully done. The only issue graphics-wise would be the walking animation. I didn't notice it too much until I was almost finished with the game, but the characters legs look strange when she walks, it does not work smoothly. 

The biggest issue with the game would have to  be the ending. I knew that I was nearing the end, but instead of finishing the storyline, it basically was one last click and then I was brought to a big "game over" screen. The game was mostly wrapped up, but it needed a few more lines of dialogue and/or another cutscene to properly bring the game to an end. It was rather jarring. 

Overall, for the asking price, especially if you can get it on sale, I would recommend this game if you are a point-and-click adventure fan. 

Pros:
+Graphics/Artstyle
+Decent writing, if not as refined as one may like
+Clear, non-frustrating puzzles
+Low asking price

Neutral:
+/- Short game length (can be a pro or con depending on the person's interest in the game)

Cons:
-Not great voice acting 
-Abrupt and unsatisfying ending

author: {'steamid': '76561198137983877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1471875246}
review:
[b]Belladonna is a short point & click adventure game developed by Neckbolt and published by Black Shell Media inspired by Mary Shelley‚Äôs novel, Frankenstein and The Modern Prometheus ..[/b]
 First of all i would like to let you know that Belladonna is not a bad game at all, but not a good one either, the developers had a great idea for their game but sadly they didn't know how to fully use it and implement it what made it feel like its still incomplete and missing many things, especially the ending; it  was acceptable for such a linear story but to be honest this got me so disappointed
The voice acting is good, the artwork is nice and well-drawn and the "few" puzzles are so easy to solve
The story is so short (1-2 hours depending on your reading speed, and yes .. if you don't like reading games don't even bother buying it ^^) and after you finish it you'll find yourself missing some trading cards what oblige you to idle it for few more hours if you do care about these stuff
To conclude with, this is one of the times where i wish steam had a "meh, it's acceptable" option, this game could be so good for newbies to the genre, other than that there is no real reason to prefer it on the other point & click games out there on the market.    5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197967951581', 'num_games_owned': 2682, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1465023582}
review:
Enjoyable story based point and click game. My main problem really is that this game walks right up to the very edge of compelling narratives and then dismisses them and moves on. A character muses on a moral quandry that would make for a really interesting turn in the game, twice, and then just dismisses them. There is a vague reason for it in the narrative, but given the short playtime, it's frustrating that interesting content is teased but never delivered.

Also, given that the main character is a reanimated corpse, I'm not sure if the voice acting was well done or a bit off. Could have totally been intentional.

A less important issue is that the game has 7 trading cards, but playing this through to 100% completion took me a little under one hour. With no more content to see, I just have to leave this running in the background as I wait for the rest of the cards. A bit troublesome, but not so much as to take away from the Frankenstien inspired narrative.

I wouldn't pay $7 for it, but given I grabbed it at a steep discount, it was worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077145145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1482946666}
review:
It's a strange feeling to pay 57p for a game yet feel oddly cheated after completing it.

In short, my main issues were:

-Makes tons of literary references (to the point of becoming annoying), yet does nothing to build upon said works to present something new or different. 

-One of the most interesting premises and moral issues of the game is brought up at the very end, yet rather than starting this game from this point (which could have set the stage for an even  darker but truly deep game that made use of its literary references) or at least continuing on for another chapter, one of the characters immediately dismisses the concern and leaves us with well-drawn, but uttering disappointing end screen.

-Voice acting does not fit the setting or characters at all. The actors really do give it their all, but the acting did not fit the gothic setting.

The game is very short, which isn't necessarily a bad thing as long as that's the amount of time the game needs to say and achieve what it wants to. Belladonna, though interesting enough to hang on through minimal puzzle-solving/ item finding, only begins to come alive (pun intended) at its very end, which is a shame.

Despite all of this, I truly hope the developers continue to make games,  Belladonna is not a bad game, in fact, if it was, then I simply would have dismissed it entirely and not bothered writing this review. 

What makes Belladonna so frustrating is that is has so much potential- interesting subject matter, good artwork, ethical issues, etc- but doesn't fully execute on those elements and ends before it truly begins. I will, however, keep an eye out for future games from this company. They have the ideas, they just have to take that final step.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049061232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1472484444}
review:
Ok, let me put it plainly. This isnt looking like a complete game. The whole game can be played under less than a couple hours with no speeding WHATSOEVER. It really is made with little content at all!

I would have wanted to start with the pro's, rather than con's, but...there are very little pro's to it:

- the concept: it is sort of interesting, sadly it remained what it was, a concept;
- SOME, and i mean SOME of the visuals are truly keeping up with the graphic style entirely;
- voice acting: Klara is rather nicely acted, a nice voice to listen to actually;

CON'S

- game content and inherently its length: are you kidding me??? The game is made out of maybe not even 10 rooms! And some of them are only used as passage from an area to the other, while other contains just a note and nothing else!
- story: the plot is almost entirely unfold through handwritten notes over and over AND over again. If that wasnt enough, they're just an image and therefore the font can't even scale up to proportion, and stays awfully small. 
- puzzles: all of the puzzles are just a joke. They take seriously no time at all to figure out, and often you're even told plainly what to do. They're not even puzzles! 
- some drawings: i chuckled as i saw Doctor's Wolf body. It has so many issues...and Belladonna isnt truly well drawn either.
- animations: oh my freaking god. Klara literally fluctuates and has no interaction whatsoever with the surroundings.
- overall lack of polish and care: room transitions carrying the description "exit" or "to the next room", truly short soundtrack looping over and over, lack of basic interaction.
- the ABRUPT ending. There's not even a cinematic at the end. Just a colorful screen with an "END" sign so you get it, at least....

In conclusion: this game was either not completely taken care of or maybe it was completed in a rush. As the story stands, it's pretty much uncompleted and feels more of a demo rather than a complete game.

review: Belladonna is a very short and quite technically simple (12 static backgrounds for sets with clumsy superimposed animations) gothic adventure game which will appeal to gamers who like walking simulators and other exploratory games where you wander around picking up journal entries and piecing together parts of a story. There's very little challenge to the intentory based puzzles in this game but I liked the story and so I had a good time playing this. I got it on sale for $1. I don't think full price is worth it for the one hour of entertainment provided.

review:
Alright, I don‚Äôt do reviews often, so I'm not a master at reviews, but this is one game that needs one.

It's a short game, not the greatest one out there, but it's decent one~ It might be better to pick this one up when it's on a good sale, but that's yours to decide. Though just a heads up on some things:

-My initial run of the game took a little under an hour, and I was taking my time with it. Not the longest game around.

Combined with the ending and I'd call it a good game at the end of the day! Though the addition of a volume control in the game itself would be wonderful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042831386', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 627, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1452713854}
review:
[h1]Short version: 87%[/h1]
Mixing the themes of Mary Shelley‚Äôs Frankenstein with a grotesque tale of love, Belladonna is an adventure game for those who like their stories a bit weird, even if it lasts barely an hour.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Belladonna is a name of conflicts: an Italian phrase that means ‚Äòbeautiful woman‚Äô, but also the name given to a somewhat bland-looking flower ‚Äì a very poisonous flower. This game, named after both, carries that strange duality: it is beautiful, but it is a game about death.

Death and reanimation, death and unlife, death and what could be considered unnatural even by the less religious people too. In short, Belladonna is a game that starts with a re-enactment of Mary Shelley‚Äôs ‚ÄòFrankenstein; or, the Modern Prometheus‚Äô‚Äì or, more precisely, the underlying theme of brining the dead back to life.
After this ghoulish start, the game follows the steps of the newly-resurrected girl who slowly discovers the reasons and events that led to her current state: a story about a marriage gone sour and a man getting obsessed with his work about creating life. A story which also has a few small twists in it, even if most are telegraphed in very obvious ways long before their big reveal.

Although this game is a point ‚Äòn‚Äô click adventure in theory, in practise few things will ever stand in the player‚Äôs way to discover the story it wants to tell. Only a handful of objects are used and most of the time the game tells how to accomplish the required objective, so the roughly one-hour game time‚Äì the only obviously sore spot about Belladonna‚Äì is spent by fully immersing ourselves in this weird, somewhat bittersweet, and maybe mildly disturbing tale.

review:
You awaken in a laboratory not knowing who you are. Your head is shaved and you have a strange mechanism coming out of your head. You need to get out and figure out what's going on. Soon you realize that the house belongs to a Frankenstein-ish kind of doctor, who have learned how to raise dead. It wasn't him who brought you back though, as you soon find out.

The graphics in this game are amazing and the main heroine - the arizen lesbian maid - is great. The story is a bit short, but  for an indie game it's magnificent.

I highly recommend this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164151349', 'num_games_owned': 2681, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1461789780}
review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
A short point-n-click adventure game where you play a reanimated zombie girl who tries to find out what happened to her. Took me 40 minutes to complete. I paid S$0.75 (~US$0.56) for this during sale.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+ Nice graphics
+ OK music
+ Decent voice acting
+ Pleasant gaming experience
+ Fascinating story - really knows how to hook you
+ Characters are well-developed

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
- Couldn't find a "save game" option anywhere
- Way too short for the price
- Puzzles far too simple
- Voice & text speed do not match
- Voice sometimes gets cut off once text disappears
- Text sometimes disappears if voice is too fast
- Zero replayability
- No Steam achievements
- No trading cards ([url=steamcommunity.com/app/351340/discussions/0/535152511373786456/]unless you leave the game running for several hours[/url])
- Only 1 ending
- Ending is horribly abrupt: [i]"The End"[/i] flashes and that's it!!!

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
Only get this during sale. It's very short and the ending was a huge massive gargantuan disappointment. But I did enjoy playing through the game because the story was intriguing (though also predictable), and the graphics and environment done pretty well. I hated the lack of a "save game" option.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994992633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1457865935}
review:
At times, there are some games that the themes are quite obvious ‚Äì that‚Äôs a good thing however there are others that sends out mixed messages. Belladonna from developer Neckbolt forms the latter. On the initial onset, it promises a gothic adventure filled with various themes like who‚Äôs the real villain and morale value systems. Yet when completing the game, there were very minimalistic morale systems as quite frankly, there was no choices to be made. In addition, the dominate feeling I had was, this is some kind a high school / first year university project played on primitive philosophy.

The plot encompasses the story loosely based on Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley‚Äôs Frankenstein. That is, the doctor Wolfram von Trauerschloss had a vision to reanimate the dead. Of course he has his own reasons thus forms the plot. To enhance the plot, there are scattered journal notes that are extremely well written, yet a little too pretentious at times, along with the spoken dialogues that gives out an impression of superiority among the readers. Also, as much as I enjoyed reading the journal notes, this places too much dominance over the said gameplay style, which is an adventure game.

Yet the strong points of this ‚Äògame‚Äô is the atmosphere it creates and most of that was due to its musical scores. The music was indeed haunting and does loop eventually. However the looping is so well done that you won‚Äôt notice it for the most parts. Every dialogues are voice acted and does a reasonable job at it. Visually it‚Äôs simplistic yet effective. There won‚Äôt be any pixel hunting as there‚Äôs not much inventory management to begin with. The drawings are all displayed with great detail, especially the opening scene where the female protagonist wakes up from her ‚Äòsleep‚Äô.

Depending upon your reading speed, this game can be completed within an hour or so. It took me about two hours however I was very meticulous with all of my actions. With a price tag of USD $6.99, that‚Äôs not a good deal. I was hoping there were morale choices or at minimal, two endings. The game, whilst promises various themes and morale systems, the game ultimately is linear. Other words, it really doesn‚Äôt matter what I think as the game has a starting and ending point so basically I‚Äôm taking the viewpoint of the developer‚Äôs ‚Äòideal‚Äô choice.

The game doesn‚Äôt even have a thought provoking ending where it makes the player contemplate for the moment (for instance David Lynch‚Äôs ‚ÄòLost Highway‚Äô) and that would be an acceptable ending to a linear game however it was not the case. Also the game‚Äôs mix messages it‚Äôs sending out leads for more confusion (for instance, looking at the trading cards, is it taking the mickey out of old horror films or is Neckbolt a fan of this genre?). This clashes to the ‚Äòmoralistic‚Äô approach to this game. So it looks like Neckbolt had some sort of story to share however couldn‚Äôt think of an appropriate gaming genre so it uses the ‚Äòadventure‚Äô genre as the be-all-end-all.

If it meant to be a philosophical journey, as mentioned before, it‚Äôs coming across as pretentious. Neckbolt should take a page out of a great philosophical fictional novel ‚ÄòSophie‚Äôs World‚Äô by Jostein Gaarder. The author uses words that can appeal to the wider audience without sounding haughty that also gets the message across. Because this game missed the queue too many times, I really cannot recommend it at its current price. If the price is maximum USD $2.99 then it can be somewhat forgiven.

4 / 10

review:
Dies ist das perfekte Spiel f√ºr diejenigen, die wollen, dass ihre Abenteuer-Genre zu starten. Andere Spiele in diesem Genre kann auch schwierig sein (von Puzzles), zu lang oder zu verr√ºckt (mit ihrer Geschichte), aber die "Belladonna" ist sehr gut geschrieben, hat ein paar R√§tsel, sch√∂ne Charaktere und Hintergr√ºnde. Dies ist ein perfektes Beispiel.

Auf der anderen Seite, f√ºr die Veteranen der Abenteuerspiele, kann dieses Spiel zu kurz erscheinen (etwa eine Stunde Spiel), so dass bei√üt ein wenig verloren Gelegenheit, mehr Umgebungen hinzuzuf√ºgen, setzen die n√§chste R√§tsel, Zeichen und Dialog.
Niklas Hallin - Aber dieses Spiel wurde von einer Person gemacht. Damit erkl√§rt sich die L√§nge des Spiels.

Trotz der Tatsache, dass dieses Spiel f√ºr die kurze und zu einfach ist, die Abenteuer essen zum Fr√ºhst√ºck "Belladonna" ist einzigartig - ein Stil und das Aussehen der Hauptfigur - es weder gut noch schlecht ist, und dies f√ºgt ein wenig Tiefe, um das allgemeine Gef√ºhl.

Oh, und noch eine Sache - die Entwickler selbst einmal auf seiner Website geschrieben, die seine Arbeit weitgehend nicht auf die anderen Spiele modelliert wird, aber in der Literatur. Ich kann sagen, dass es wirklich f√ºhlt, vor allem, wenn die Seiten zerrissen von Tageb√ºcher zu lesen "Belladonnay."

Alles in allem empfehle ich dieses Spiel f√ºr die Menschen sehr, die die Atmosph√§re, die Charaktere und Geschichten in jedem Spiel zu sch√§tzen wissen. Und diejenigen, die nur wie ein langes Spiel und herausfordernde R√§tsel scheitern.

review:
Welp... that's some dark stuff going in here. Preeeetty dark stuff. Ugh.
I love this game's soundtrack and graphic. I love Klara's voice, appearance and movement. I love the tension and sudden noises which caused faster heartbeat.
I love the story even though it's so sad and depressing.
But I do feel like this game is so damn short it's simply cannot be accepted. We need a sequel, a good long sequel with [spoiler!] Klara ruling the world along with Belladonna.
I'm not a real fan of lesbian love but well, things like that happen and it comes to the point if we accept it or not. I don't mind but hey - Klara is so pretty and Belladonna just looks... old (and a lil bit like Cruella De'mon (coincidence?)). But I guess everyone needs some love in this dark, cold place.
Still don't know what do I feel after playing. Maybe a lil bit of disgust (chopping the head of a corpse then carrying it around the house, why not?)
God bless Klara's voice actress.

Overall, I approve. Even though I'm a little tired of this "dead comes back to life" and "evil scientist" cliches.

review: I enjoyed this game very much for what it was. It's not super challenging or super long but it wasn't boring either. A semi original plotline that was enjoyable to play along and figure out. You will however spend a lot of time reading on your first playthrough, as there are a lot of journal pages to collect, which can get tedious but for me it was necessary to the plotline. Overall I would recommend this game as a distraction from another game or if you just want to play a quick one. I would rate it about 6 out of 10 will play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050705438', 'num_games_owned': 1769, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1456985840}
review:
Ich hatte mich echt auf dieses Spiel gefreut. Die Screenshots sahen gut aus, die Story h√∂rte sich ganz gut an und der Einschlag von Mary Shelleys Frankenstein sprechen eigentlich f√ºr ein gutes Spiel.
Was ich jedoch bekam, war ein eher fragw√ºrdiges Machwerk.

Zuerst einmal das Positive am Spiel, davon gibt es, trotz vieler Kritikpunkte, einiges. Mir gef√§llt der Grafikstil des Spiels sehr. die Hintergr√ºnde, Objekte und Charaktere sind sehr sch√∂n gezeichnet, man erkennt die Liebe, die darin steckt. Auch das Voiceacting finde ich sehr gut, welches haupts√§chlich von der Protagonistin des Spiels kommt. Man hat hier definitiv die richtige Sprecherin gew√§hlt, die Stimme passt perfekt zum Charakter.
Die Spielelemente sind sehr leicht zu bedienen, kein Wunder, man speilt es nur mit einer Taste, der linken Maustaste.

Das alles kann aber nicht dar√ºber hinwegt√§uschen, dass Belladonna in Wahrheit ein scheu√üliches Spiel ist. Scheu√ülich ist vielleicht etwas hart ausgedr√ºckt, meiner Meinung nach aber angemessen. Ich erkenne die M√ºhe an, die der Entwickler in dieses Spiel gesteckt hat, aber durch viel M√ºhe entwickelt man noch lange kein gutes Spiel.
Was Belladonna nun so schlecht macht, ist an vielen Punkten abzusehen. 
Zum einen ist es kurz. Ein kurzes Spiel muss nicht automatisch schlecht sein, aber dieses Spiel ist bereits nach einer halben Stunde bis Stunde (je nachdem, ob man schneller oder langsamer liest) abgegrast. Die Spielzeit wurde hierbei sogar noch k√ºnstlich durch mehrere Aspekte verl√§ngert. Zum einen bewegt sich die Protagonistin sehr langsam, dies kann man nicht beschleunigen, indem man doppel klickt. Ein Schnelreisesystem existiert auch nicht, mit dem man schnell von Zimmer zu Zimmer reisen k√∂nnte, indem man Laufanimationen √ºberspringt. Viel schlimmer als das sind jedoch die Kommentare der Spielfigur. Wie in einem Adventure √ºblich, sagt unsere Heldin zu jedem Gegenstand etwas, was an sich nicht st√∂rend ist, da das Voice Acting sehr gut ist. Allerdings kann man Texte nicht √ºberspringen. zwar verschwindet der Text auf dem Bildschirm, aber die Spielfigur redet weiter. W√§hrenddessen kann man nichts tun, weder sich bewegen, noch Gegenst√§nde benutzen, man muss warten, bis dieser Monolog beendet ist, was die ganze Situation nur noch viel schlimmer macht. Hier mal falsch geklickt und schon muss man wieder 3 S√§tze warten. Dadurch wird die Spielzeit sehr gestreckt, ich sch√§tze um 10 weitere Minuten.

Was ich besonders lieblos finde, ist die Geschichte. Obwohl sie sich zuerst sehr interessant anh√∂rte, liest sich das ganze baald wie eine typische 08/15 Fanfiction aus dem Internet. Und zwar keine gute.
Ich m√∂chte hier einmal kurz anmerken, dass jetzt gewaltige Spoiler zur Spielgeschichte folgen werden, die das ende schon vorwegnehmen. Nicht, dass es besonders gut durchdacht w√§re. Die Handlung l√§sst sich auch viel k√ºrzer abdecken, als sie im Spiel durch die zahlreichen und langatmigen Tagebucheintr√§ge abgehandelt wird.


[spoiler]Die H√§lfte der Geschichte wird im Grunde genommen schon auf der Shopseite erkl√§rt, sogar die aller erste Tagebuchseite, die man direkt am Anfang findet, erkl√§rt im grunde genommen das ganze Spiel.
Der Landgutbesitzer udn Wissenschaftler Dr. Wolfram von Trauerschloss (ganz klar eine Anspielung an Victor von Frankenstein) verliert seinen Sohn w√§hrend dieser noch im Babyalter ist. Seien Frau st√ºrzt es in eine tiefe Depression, ihn treibt es an grauenvolle Experimente durchzuf√ºhren. er versucht Herr √ºber Leben und Tod zu werden und toten K√∂rpern neues Leben einzuhauchen um so seinen verstorbenen Sohn wiederzuerwecken. Seine Dienerschaft ist von diesen experimenten angeekelt und fl√ºchten vom Schloss. Einzig eine Magd bleibt, die fortan alle Aufgaben im Haushalt erf√ºllt.
Dies tut sie nicht aus Treue, sondern weil sie sich in die Frau des werten Doktors verguckt hat, weshalb sie zu keinem Zeitpunkt von deren Seite weichen m√∂chte.
Irgendwann ergibt es sich, warum wird nicht im Spiel n√§her erl√§utert, dass Schlossfr√§ulein und Magd ein Liebesverh√§ltnis eingehen und das ganze Schloss nach neuen Liebesnestern durchstreifen, immer bei dem Versuch Dr. von Trauerschloss aus dem Weg zu gehen. Dieser kommt dennoch hinter die sehr verst√∂rende Aff√§re (er hatte mit sowas gerechnet, aber er dachte, sie w√ºrde einen Mann treffen) und das treibt ihn immer mehr in den Wahnsinn. Er fasst den Plan, die Dienstmagd mit Gift zu ermorden, damit er seien Frau wieder f√ºr sich hat. Diese ist nach dem Mord jedoch so aufgebracht, dass er sie ebenfalls umbringt und danach mit seinen experimenten wieder als mechanische Puppe zum Leben erweckt. Durch diese Verwandlung ist sie nun wie ein Spielzeug f√ºr ihn, er kann sie befehligen und sie gehorcht jedes seiner Worte. Allerdings entwickelt seine Frau ihre eigene Pers√∂nlichkeit zur√ºck, ermordet ihren Gatten, erweckt ihre Geliebte wieder zum Leben (die ihr spielt), aber kann eure Auferstehung nicht miterleben, da ihr vorher der Sprit ausgeht (scheinbar m√ºssen die Untoten in diesem Spiel wie Speilzeuge aufgezogen werden). Das Spiel kickt ein, ihr durchsucht das Haus, l√∂st kleine Nicht-Puzzle bis ihr eure Geliebte starr im Schlafzimemr findet udn sie wieder aufzieht. Die ist nat√ºrlich h√∂chst erfreut und zusammen plant ihr den Doktor, llerdings mit dem Hirn des verstorbenen Sohnes, nciht seinem eigenem, wiederzuerwecken und danach wollt ihr eine ganze armee an Untoten erschaffen und eure eigene Gesellschaft gr√ºnden. Dabei wird angedeutet, dass sowohl eure Spielfigur als auch die werte Schlossherrin keinerlei Mitgef√ºhl f√ºr die Lebenden empfinden k√∂nnen und deshalb grausame M√∂rder in die Welt schaffen. Im Abschlussbild werden dann all die grausigen Untoten gezeigt, samt eurer Spielfigur, die ihrer Herrin zu F√º√üen liegt und wie ein Haustier oder eine Sklavin ihre Kn√∂chel umarmt. Sehr verst√∂rrend.[/spoiler] 

U dem Spiel den Todesspiel zu geben: es ist an sich nichtmal ein Spiel. Mittlerweile sind sogenannte "Walking Simulator" sehr in Mode gekommen, die alleine deshalb existieren, um durch eien inszenierte Spielwelt zu laufen udn dabei die Spielgeschichte zu h√∂ren. Richtige Spielemente gibt es nicht und man k√∂nnte sich sogar den akt des Laufens eigentlich sparen. Die wenigen "Puzzle" im Spiel sind nicht anspruchsvoll und das ergebnis wird euch schon vorher auf dem Pr√§sentierteller geliefert. eins der schlimmsten, dass ich fand, war, wo man Zahnr√§der in die passenden L√∂cher stecken muss. Dies war haargenau wie das spielzeug von Kleinkindern, wo diese die richtigen Formen in die richtigen L√∂cher tun mussten. Der Entwickler stellt somit den Intellekt der Spieler mit dem von Kleinkindern auf eine Stufe. Ich war richtig beleidigt √ºber dieses "R√§tsel". Das war allerdings auch schon das schlimmste, alle anderen waren, wenn auch kaum merklich, besser.
Hier und da gab es auch ein paar Bugs, das Spiel ist aber im gro√üen ganzen bugfrei. Nur ein bug, der mir mehrmals auffiel, st√∂rt mich sehr, der auch wieder die Spielzeit in die L√§nge zog. ein paar Mal versagte das Pathfinding der Spielfigur, obwohl man etwas anklickte, wollte sie sich nicht dorthin bewegen. Man musste erstmal den weg herum anklicken, bis sie schlie√ülich nah genug daran war, damit das Pathfinding wieder wusste, wo es lang ging.

Eine kleine abschlussbemerkung noch: Das Spiel besitzt ganze 13 (!) Sammelkarten. Ein weiterer trauriger versuch, die Spielzeit k√ºnstlich zu verl√§ngern. Ich habe w√§hrend meines Spieldurchlaufs nur eine Karte gekriegt, viele kriegen sogar GAR KEINE beim ersten durchlauf und der Entwickler selbst sagt, dass man 1-2 Karten pro Spieldurchlauf maximal kriegt (und das ist hoch gepokert). Da man pro Krte etwa 30 minuten warten muss, kommt man so bei 7 Karten locker auf 3,5 Stunden Spielzeit. Dies l√§sst das spiel viel l√§nger f√ºr Au√üenstehende erscheinen, als es in Wirklichkeit ist.

Alles in allem finde ich, dass das Spiel nicht seien 7 Euro wert ist, nichtmal die H√§lfte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026720425', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1452421198}
review:
Belladonna is short, actually it's a very short game. It took me a little bit more than 1 hour to finish it and I even did get stuck at point. But it's short gameplay time is the game's only fault.

Belladonna can best be described as a true classic gothic horror story. Most modern day horror games usually rely on jump scares and horrific images to create their "atmospheric" gameplay. Belladonna in contrast is using a completely different approach. By relying on a story progression similar to a detective story, the horrible truth of what dark deeds had been done, will be gradually presented to the player. This way the game manages to create it's dark and brooding atmosphere and keep the player interested in what has been happening.

Gameplay itself is your standard point-and-click adventure style, without pixel-hunting. Interactable objects will always be indentified as those (maybe except for one occasion where I got stuck XD).

Overall. Belladonna is definitely worth playing. Just keep in mind that it is quite short, so maybe wait for a sale to pick it up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117950822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1857, 'last_played': 1455445550}
review:
I ave conflicting opinions about this gam. The puzzles are so simple yuo'd think the game was aimed at children, but the subject matter isn't suitable. I'll get straight into the pros and cons and then you can make up your own mind.

[h1] What's good [/h1]
+ Relatively atmospheric
+ Engaging if traditional mad scientist type story
+ Reasonably priced (paticularly if you pick it up in a sale like I did!)
+ Lots of steam cards

[h1]What's not[/h1]
- Pretty short
- Puzzles are a bit too easy
- Animation/art is a little odd at times
- No real replayability
- No volume controls - meaing that to get all the many card drops I needed to leave this running with the PC volume on silent for 30 hours. For a game that's 2 to 3 hours long that's a little annoying

All in all - ok for a couple of hours of non-challenging gaming it you're running out of point and clicks to play (like I am).

author: {'steamid': '76561198202896657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1453923826}
review: Sadly, I was disappointed with this game. It starts out very slowly, and right when it gets really interesting, it's suddenly over. As others already said, there is very little room to figure things out by yourself as the main character basically tells you the next step you should take while she is narrating. I also had problems with the cat part. Not even a trigger warning about it?? :( I almost wanted to stop playing because I got so upset. What happened was important to the storyline, BUT since the game has such a rushed ending, it felt pointless. The graphics are really nice, though, and I liked the story we read in the diary pages. I just wish that the letters were bigger, since it was really very hard to read! And to talk about the music: The track is nice, but gets really boring/annoying since it is the only thing you'll ever hear in the game. On loop. I do not recommend this game to anyone. Sorry. :(

review:
[b]Belladonna[/b] it's an indie Point & Click game. That reminds those old legends of the mad scientists and their abominations [u](such as Frankenstein, The doctor Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, among others)[/u], themed with a gothic / horror atmosphere, belladonna would have been an indie game that you should own, i mean there are many facts that makes this game interesting:
[list][*] Great atmosphere.
[*] Visually friendly.
[*] Amazing background art.
[*] Nice background music.
[*] In-game story is so good, until certain point.[/list]

The story begins when you awake from an eternal dream [i](you are a re-animated corpse from which once was a girl)[/i], in a scientist laboratory. Without memories of your past or thoughts that what happened, during the walkthrough you will find notes that tell the true story about the place in where are you and you.

[h1]These points makes it just another failed attempt of a great game.[/h1]
[list][*] Voice acting is quite boring, i mean the voice of the girl is great, but the way that she talk don't.
[*] The game is too short.
[*] In-game hidden objects and objectives are too obvious.
[*] The final it's kind confusing. [/list]

Story would be great if it would be bigger and more difficult.

[b]Final score:[/b]
[b]‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ[/b]
Not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025598384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1455026766}
review:
I try to buy indie games at or close to full price, particularly from first time developers who do something that looks cool or interesting. Sure, I've taken a bath on a couple of games that weren't as good as I'd hoped, but it's never been too punishing.

Until now.

Belladonna is the first game that I truly, [i]sorely[/i] regret buying. Even if I had a time machine and could go back and buy it dirt cheap, knowing what I know now, [i]I still wouldn't[/i]. As I write this review, it's currently on sale for sixty-nine cents and my brain is still going, "NOPE." Listen to my brain. It knows what it's talking about. Don't make the same mistakes I did. By all means, laugh at my pain, but save yourselves.

Ostensibly, Belladonna is a point and click adventure game consisting of exploration, a mystery narrative and puzzles. That assessment is...generous, at the very least. 

In a game that takes place in what's supposed to be a [i]castle[/i], there are about a dozen locations, [i]including hallways.[/i] Most contain one item--two if you're extremely lucky!--and maybe two or three short bits of flavor text so bland I hesitate to call it flavor text at all. If light vegan mayonnaise were flavor text, it's what you'll find here. I guess if you've never had anything else, it might seem robust, but I can't imagine anyone with half a dozen decent-to-good adventure games under their belts finding it anything but dull.

The narrative isn't much better than the flavor(less) text. The plot hinges on a mystery so transparent it's easily solvable after the first clue or two if you've got a couple of spare braincells lying around to rub together. Halfway through the story, you're likely to get fed up with how it's belaboring the point you've already figured out. ‚ÄúI know something you don't know!‚Äù the narrative teases, ‚ÄúSuch a mysterious mystery! Oooh!‚Äù while you start drinking heavily and praying for the sweet release of death.

The prose is written in a style that I can only adequately describe as ‚Äúolden time-y,‚Äù superficially reminiscent of Gothic literature if you tossed any old novel in a blender and diluted it with heavy doses of pretentious goth kid who swallowed a thesaurus but neglected to get enough dictionary in his diet.  This might not be so bad if the story and characters were stylish or over the top enough to carry the awkwardness‚ÄîHammer or Universal horror films are hardly historically accurate, but are cool enough you don't care‚Äîbut Belladonna has the panache of a worn out shoe.

The story is told primarily through diary entries written by three different characters: the scientist, his socialite wife and the maid. They all sound virtually the same. The only discernible difference between them is that our Frankenstein writes in a slightly more ornate style and throws a few scientific terms around. I repeat: a socialite and a scientist both write the same way a maid does. In the Georgian/Victorian era. (Which is it? Who knows!)

The diary entries also contain only explicitly plot related bits with nothing else to really round out the characters. They're basically props to be moved around at the whim of the developer like little cardboard cutouts. This is not the way to tell a story with any hope of emotional potency. The villain gets what feels like three times as much ‚Äúscreen time‚Äù through the diaries as the two main characters we're supposed to care about‚Äîand he's dead before the story even starts!

Because the whole thing is written as telling rather than showing, in spite of the fact it's all plot, the relationships between the characters are barely touched on in any meaningful way. The main romance is written about in detail‚Äîas in, what actually happened between them during the course of their months long affair‚Äîin [i]one entry[/i]; it's given no development beyond that.

Character motives are thin on the ground. The writer tries to convey that the characters are driven by grief, but does so poorly that I'm not sure they've ever met and interacted with a real live human being. Since the story picks up [i]after both characters in question are through grieving[/i], their motivations appear for all intents and purposes to consist of such compelling reasons as, ‚ÄúBecause science! I guess?‚Äù and ‚ÄúBecause boredom! I guess?‚Äù

The puzzles would be insultingly easy to even the most casual of gamers over the age of nine. And though I may have blocked out the more excruciating aspects of the experience, as far as I can recall with the exception of the final one, they all have the same basic end goal: open a door/container. That's it. Kill a cat to open a door. Rifle through a dead body's pockets to open a box. Get a screwdriver to open a clock. Necessary items for solving these ‚Äúpuzzles‚Äù are often just left lying around in plain sight, require no extra steps to acquire them and no critical thinking to make them function. Can you put two and two together and not come up with ‚Äúcheese‚Äù? Congratulations, you too can finish Belladonna!

Worst of all, [i]nothing happens[/i]. Nothing. Because everything has [i]already[/i] happened. This narrative device [i]can[/i] work in games (Analogue: A Hate Story managed to pull this off pretty handily) but the writing is so lousy that even the attempt is torture. After forty-five minutes of opening doors, it finally looks like something will happen!...and then the story cuts to black. The end!

If for some reason‚Äîmasochism, morbid curiosity, a large iron spike in your head tickling the 'lack of common sense' centers of your brain‚Äîyou're still considering shelling out dough to buy this, let me at least mention that the less story-based aspects suffer too in hopes I might dissuade you from such folly. 

First, the voice acting is dismal and one actor portrays both speaking characters: the first in a plain American speaking voice, the second with electronic distortion and a high school play English accent. Never mind that this apparently takes place in Eastern Europe or...Germany? (Much like the time period, who the fuck knows for sure??)

The diary entries are all written in fonts that border on unreadable to various degrees. They're either too flowery, too tiny, or joy of joys both.

It's bare bones in the extreme. There are no extras. No behind the scenes character art or similar unlockables. No achievements. [i]No save button.[/i] Now that's commitment to minimalism!

Replayability is nonexistent.

If after all this you still want the game, well...Godspeed, you beautiful, romantic fool. I envy your optimism, naivete and by the way would you like to buy a bridge in Brooklyn?

In closing, I will say: if Belladonna were updated in the future and whole swaths of it were rewritten, expanded and for the love of all that's holy [i]edited[/i], it might be something special, or at least an interesting if noble failure. Currently it is anything but. My playtime will be just long enough to collect all the cards and not a second longer.

2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198099216008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1454798241}
review:
This game is cute, in a dark and twisted kind of way. I'd give it 5/10, and I recommend it only because it's 0,69‚Ç¨ now, and for that price it's a total catch.
PROS:
+ I loved the artwork and the general environment.
+ Music wasn't annoying, and voice acting was ok.
+ I liked the Steampunk vibe, the theme, and the story was cool.
+ References to Mary Shelley and Edgar Allan Poe, which made me squeal in delight.
+ Easy and logical, there is no constant backtracking, no pixel hunt, and no nonsensical inventory combinations.

CONS:
- Extremely short. I'm a VERY slow player, and I finished it in 2 hours, and that is including a pause I took for dinner while leaving the game on.
- Too easy. Not one puzzle and not one remotely challenging situation.
- The ending leaves lose ends, almost as if hoping for a sequel.

In short, if on sale, go for it. It's a nice hour and bit of a dark little story. But if you're into really challenging stuff, this one may bore you a bit. I still enjoy it and I'm not sorry I got it (then again, I got it for 0,69‚Ç¨).
